books.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 1

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 1:1
verses.text: Book I  Chapter I.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 1:2
verses.text: The Office of the Instructor.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 1:3
verses.text: As there are these three things in the case of man, habits, actions, and passions; habits are the department appropriated by hortatory discourse the guide to piety, which, like the ship's keel, is laid beneath for the building up of faith; in which, rejoicing exceedingly, and abjuring our old opinions, through salvation we renew our youth, singing with the hymning prophecy, "How good is God to Israel, to such as are upright in heart!" All actions, again, are the province of preceptive discourse; while persuasive discourse applies itself to heal the passions.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 1:4
verses.text: It is, however, one and the self-same word which rescues man from the custom of this world in which he has been reared, and trains him up in the one salvation of faith in God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 1:5
verses.text: When, then, the heavenly guide, the Word, was inviting men to salvation, the appellation of hortatory was properly applied to Him: his same word was called rousing (the whole from a part).

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 1:6
verses.text: For the whole of piety is hortatory, engendering in the kindred faculty of reason a yearning after true life now and to come.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 1:7
verses.text: But now, being at once curative and preceptive, following in His own steps, He makes what had been prescribed the subject of persuasion, promising the cure of the passions within us.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 1:8
verses.text: Let us then designate this Word appropriately by the one name Tutor (or Paedagogue, or Instructor).

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 1:9
verses.text: The Instructor being practical, not theoretical, His aim is thus to improve the soul, not to teach, and to train it up to a virtuous, not to an intellectual life.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 1:10
verses.text: Although this same word is didactic, but not in the present instance.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 1:11
verses.text: For the word which, in matters of doctrine, explains and reveals, is that whose province it is to teach.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 1:12
verses.text: But our Educator being practical, first exhorts to the attainment of right dispositions and character, and then persuades us to the energetic practice of our duties, enjoining on us pure commandments, and exhibiting to such as come after representations of those who formerly wandered in error.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 1:13
verses.text: Both are of the highest utility,—that which assumes the form of counselling to obedience, and that which is presented in the form of example; which latter is of two kinds, corresponding to the former duality,—the one having for its purpose that we should choose and imitate the good, and the other that we should reject and turn away from the opposite.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 1:14
verses.text: Hence accordingly ensues the healing of our passions, in consequence of the assuagements of those examples; the Paedagogue strengthening our souls, and by His benign commands, as by gentle medicines, guiding the sick to the perfect knowledge of the truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 1:15
verses.text: There is a wide difference between health and knowledge; for the latter is produced by learning, the former by healing.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 1:16
verses.text: One, who is ill, will not therefore learn any branch of instruction till he is quite well.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 1:17
verses.text: For neither to learners nor to the sick is each injunction invariably expressed similarly; but to the former in such a way as to lead to knowledge, and to the latter to health.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 1:18
verses.text: As, then, for those of us who are diseased in body a physician is required, so also those who are diseased in soul require a paedagogue to cure our maladies; and then a teacher, to train and guide the soul to all requisite knowledge when it is made able to admit the revelation of the Word.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 1:19
verses.text: Eagerly desiring, then, to perfect us by a gradation conducive to salvation, suited for efficacious discipline, a beautiful arrangement is observed by the all-benignant Word, who first exhorts, then trains, and finally teaches.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 2

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 2:1
verses.text: Chapter 2—Our Instructor's Treatment of Our Sins.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 2:2
verses.text: Now, O you, my children, our Instructor is like His Father God, whose son He is, sinless,  blameless, and with a soul devoid of passion; God in the form of man, stainless, the minister of His Father's will, the Word who is God, who is in the Father, who is at the Father's right hand, and with the form of God is God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 2:3
verses.text: He is to us a spotless image; to Him we are to try with all our might to assimilate our souls.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 2:4
verses.text: He is wholly free from human passions; wherefore also He alone is judge, because He alone is sinless.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 2:5
verses.text: As far, however, as we can, let us try to sin as little as possible.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 2:6
verses.text: For nothing is so urgent in the first place as deliverance from passions and disorders, and then the checking of our liability to fall into sins that have become habitual.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 2:7
verses.text: It is best, therefore, not to sin at all in any way, which we assert to be the prerogative of God alone; next to keep clear of voluntary transgressions, which is characteristic of the wise man; thirdly, not to fall into many involuntary offences, which is peculiar to those who have been excellently trained.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 2:8
verses.text: Not to continue long in sins, let that be ranked last.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 2:9
verses.text: But this also is salutary to those who are called back to repentance, to renew the contest.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 2:10
verses.text: And the Instructor, as I think, very beautifully says, through Moses: "If any one die suddenly by him, straightway the head of his consecration shall be polluted, and shall be shaved," designating involuntary sin as sudden death.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 2:11
verses.text: And He says that it pollutes by defiling the soul: wherefore He prescribes the cure with all speed, advising the head to be instantly shaven; that is, counselling the locks of ignorance which shade the reason to be shorn clean off, that reason (whose seat is in the brain), being left bare of the dense stuff of vice, may speed its way to repentance.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 2:12
verses.text: Then after a few remarks He adds, "The days before are not reckoned irrational," by which manifestly sins are meant which are contrary to reason.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 2:13
verses.text: The involuntary act He calls "sudden," the sin He calls "irrational".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 2:14
verses.text: Wherefore the Word, the Instructor, has taken the charge of us, in order to the prevention of sin, which is contrary to reason.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 2:15
verses.text: Hence consider the expression of Scripture, "Therefore these things saith the Lord;" the sin that had been committed before is held up to reprobation by the succeeding expression "therefore," according to which the righteous judgment follows.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 2:16
verses.text: This is shown conspicuously by the prophets, when they said, "Hadst thou not sinned, He would not have uttered these threatenings".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 2:17
verses.text: "Therefore thus saith the Lord;" "Because thou hast not heard these words, therefore these things the Lord;" and, "Therefore, behold, the Lord saith".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 2:18
verses.text: For prophecy is given by reason both of obedience and disobedience: for obedience, that we may be saved; for disobedience, that we may be corrected.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 2:19
verses.text: Our Instructor, the Word, therefore cures the unnatural passions of the soul by means of exhortations.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 2:20
verses.text: For with the highest propriety the help of bodily diseases is called the healing art—an art acquired by human skill.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 2:21
verses.text: But the paternal Word is the only Paeonian physician of human infirmities, and the holy charmer of the sick soul.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 2:22
verses.text: "Save," it is said, "Thy servant, O my God, who trusteth in Thee.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 2:23
verses.text: Pity me, O Lord; for I will cry to Thee all the day".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 2:24
verses.text: For a while the "physician's art," according to Democritus, "heals the diseases of the body; wisdom frees the soul from passion".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 2:25
verses.text: But the good Instructor, the Wisdom, the Word of the Father, who made man, cares for the whole nature of His creature; the all-sufficient Physician of humanity, the Saviour, heals both body and soul.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 2:26
verses.text: "Rise up," He said to the paralytic; "take the bed on which thou liest, and go away home;" and straightway the infirm man received strength.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 2:27
verses.text: And to the dead He said, "Lazarus, go forth;" and the dead man issued from his coffin such as he was ere he died, having undergone resurrection.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 2:28
verses.text: Further, He heals the soul itself by precepts and gifts—by precepts indeed, in course of time, but being liberal in His gifts, He says to us sinners, "Thy sins be forgiven thee".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 2:29
verses.text: We, however, as soon as He conceived the thought, became His children, having had assigned us the best and most secure rank by His orderly arrangement, which first circles about the world, the heavens, and the sun's circuits, and occupies itself with the motions of the rest of the stars for man's behoof, and then busies itself with man himself, on whom all its care is concentrated; and regarding him as its greatest work, regulated his soul by wisdom and temperance, and tempered the body with beauty and proportion.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 2:30
verses.text: And whatever in human actions is right and regular, is the result of the inspiration of its rectitude and order.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 3

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 3:1
verses.text: Chapter 3—The Philanthropy of the Instructor.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 3:2
verses.text: The Lord ministers all good and all help, both as man and as God: as God, forgiving our sins; and as man, training us not to sin.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 3:3
verses.text: Man is therefore justly dear to God, since he is His workmanship.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 3:4
verses.text: The other works of creation He made by the word of command alone, but man He framed by Himself, by His own hand, and breathed into him what was peculiar to Himself.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 3:5
verses.text: What, then, was fashioned by Him, and after He likeness, either was created by God Himself as  being desirable on its own account, or was formed as being desirable on account of something else.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 3:6
verses.text: If, then, man is an object desirable for itself, then He who is good loved what is good, and the love-charm is within even in man, and is that very thing which is called the inspiration or breath of God; but if man was a desirable object on account of something else, God had no other reason for creating him, than that unless he came into being, it was not possible for God to be a good Creator, or for man to arrive at the knowledge of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 3:7
verses.text: For God would not have accomplished that on account of which man was created otherwise than by the creation of man; and what hidden power in willing God possessed, He carried fully out by the forth-putting of His might externally in the act of creating, receiving from man what He made man; and whom He had He saw, and what He wished that came to pass; and there is nothing which God cannot do.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 3:8
verses.text: Man, then, whom God made, is desirable for himself, and that which is desirable on his account is allied to him to whom it is desirable on his account; and this, too, is acceptable and liked.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 3:9
verses.text: But what is loveable, and is not also loved by Him? And man has been proved to be loveable; consequently man is loved by God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 3:10
verses.text: For how shall he not be loved for whose sake the only-begotten Son is sent from the Father's bosom, the Word of faith, the faith which is superabundant; the Lord Himself distinctly confessing and saying, "For the Father Himself loveth you, because ye have loved Me;" and again, "And hast loved them as Thou hast loved Me?" What, then, the Master desires and declares, and how He is disposed in deed and word, how He commands what is to be done, and forbids the opposite, has already been shown.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 3:11
verses.text: Plainly, then, the other kind of discourse, the didactic, is powerful and spiritual, observing precision, occupied in the contemplation of mysteries.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 3:12
verses.text: But let it stand over for the present.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 3:13
verses.text: Now, it is incumbent on us to return His love, who lovingly guides us to that life which is best; and to live in accordance with the injunctions of His will, not only fulfilling what is commanded, or guarding against what is forbidden, but turning away from some examples, and imitating others as much as we can, and thus to perform the works of the Master according to His similitude, and so fulfil what Scripture says as to our being made in His image and likeness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 3:14
verses.text: For, wandering in life as in deep darkness, we need a guide that cannot stumble or stray; and our guide is the best, not blind, as the Scripture says, "leading the blind into pits".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 3:15
verses.text: But the Word is keen-sighted, and scans the recesses of the heart.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 3:16
verses.text: As, then, that is not light which enlightens not, nor motion that moves not, nor loving which loves not, so neither is that good which profits not, nor guides to salvation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 3:17
verses.text: Let us then aim at the fulfilment of the commandments by the works of the Lord; for the Word Himself also, having openly become flesh, exhibited the same virtue, both practical and contemplative.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 3:18
verses.text: Wherefore let us regard the Word as law, and His commands and counsels as the short and straight paths to immortality; for His precepts are full of persuasion, not of fear.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:1
verses.text: Chapter 4—Men and Women Alike Under the Instructor's Charge.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:2
verses.text: Let us, then, embracing more and more this good obedience, give ourselves to the Lord; clinging to what is surest, the cable of faith in Him, and understanding that the virtue of man and woman is the same.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:3
verses.text: For if the God of both is one, the master of both is also one; one church, one temperance, one modesty; their food is common, marriage an equal yoke; respiration, sight, hearing, knowledge, hope, obedience, love all alike.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:4
verses.text: And those whose life is common, have common graces and a common salvation; common to them are love and training.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:5
verses.text: "For in this world," he says, "they marry, and are given in marriage," in which alone the female is distinguished from the male; "but in that world it is so no more".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:6
verses.text: There the rewards of this social and holy life, which is based on conjugal union, are laid up, not for male and female, but for man, the sexual desire which divides humanity being removed.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:7
verses.text: Common therefore, too, to men and women, is the name of man.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:8
verses.text: For this reason I think the Attics called, not boys only, but girls, παιδάριον, using it as a word of common gender; if Menander the comic poet, in Rhapizomena, appears to any one a sufficient authority, who thus speaks:—  "My little daughter; for by nature The child (παιδάριον) is most loving.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:9
verses.text: Ἄρνες, too, the word for lambs, is a common name of simplicity for the male and female animal.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:10
verses.text: Now the Lord Himself will feed us as His flock forever, Amen.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:11
verses.text: But without a sheperd, neither can sheep nor any other animal live, nor children without a tutor, nor domestics without a master".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:12
verses.text: chapter 5—All Who Walk According to Truth are Children of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:13
verses.text: That, then, Paedagogy is the training of children (παίδων ἀγωγή), is clear from the word itself.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:14
verses.text: It remains for us to consider the children whom Scripture points to; then to give the paedagogue charge of them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:15
verses.text: We are the children.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:16
verses.text: In many ways Scripture celebrates us, and describes us in manifold figures of speech, giving variety to the simplicity of the faith by diverse names.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:17
verses.text: Accordingly, in the Gospel, "the Lord, standing on the shore, says to the disciples"—they happened to be fishing—"and called aloud, Children, have ye any meat?"—addressing those that were already in the position of disciples as children.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:18
verses.text: "And they brought to Him," it is said, "children, that He might put His hands on them and bless them; and when His disciples hindered them, Jesus said, Suffer the children, and forbid them not to come to Me, for of such is the kingdom of heaven".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:19
verses.text: What the expression means the Lord Himself shall declare, saying, "Except ye be converted, and become as little chidren, ye shall not enter into the kingdom of heaven;" not in that place speaking figuratively of regeneration, but setting before us, for our imitation, the simplicity that is in children.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:20
verses.text: The prophetic spirit also distinguishes us as children.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:21
verses.text: "Plucking," it is said, "branches of olives or palms, the children went forth to meet the Lord, and cried, saying, Hosanna to the Son of David! Blessed is He that cometh in the name of the Lord;" light, and glory, and praise, with supplication to the Lord: for this is the meaning of the expression Hosanna when rendered in Greek.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:22
verses.text: And the Scripture appears to me, in allusion to the prophecy just mentioned, reproachfully to upbraid the thoughtless: "Have ye never read, Out of the mouths of babes and sucklings Thou hast perfected praise?" In this way the Lord in the Gospels spurs on His disciples, urging them to attend to Him, hastening as He was to the Father; rendering His hearers more eager by the intimation that after a little He was to depart, and showing them that it was requisite that they should take more unsparing advantage of the truth than ever before, as the Word was to ascend to heaven.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:23
verses.text: Again, therefore, He calls them children; for He says, "Children, a little while I am with you".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:24
verses.text: And, again, He likens the kingdom of heaven to children sitting in the market-places and saying, "We have piped unto you, and ye have not danced; we have mourned, and ye have not lamented;" and whatever else He added agreeably thereto.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:25
verses.text: And it is not alone the Gospel that holds these sentiments.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:26
verses.text: Prophecy also agrees with it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:27
verses.text: David accordingly says, "Praise, O children, the Lord; praise the name of the Lord".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:28
verses.text: It says also by Esaias, "Here am I, and the children that God hath given me".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:29
verses.text: Are you amazed, then, to hear that men who belong to the nations are sons in the Lord's sight? You do not in that case appear to give ear to the Attic dialect, from which you may learn that beautiful, comely, and freeborn young maidens are still called παιδίσκαι, and servant-girls παιδισκάρια; and that those last also are, on account of the bloom of youth, called by the flattering name of young maidens.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:30
verses.text: And when He says, "Let my lambs stand on my right," He alludes to the simple children, as if they were sheep and lambs in nature, not men; and the lambs He counts worthy of preference, from the superior regard He has to that tenderness and simplicity of disposition in men which constitutes innocence.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:31
verses.text: Again, when He says, "as suckling calves," He again alludes figuratively to us; and "as an innocent and gentle dove," the reference is again to us.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:32
verses.text: Again, by Moses, He commands "two young pigeons or a pair of turtles to be offered for sin;" thus saying, that the harmlessness and innocence and placable nature of these tender young birds are acceptable to God, and explaining that like is an expiation for like.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:33
verses.text: Further, the timorousness of the turtle-doves typifies fear in reference to sin.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:34
verses.text: And that He calls us chickens the Scripture testifies: "As a hen gathereth her chickens under her wings".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:35
verses.text: Thus are we the Lord's chickens; the Word thus marvellously and mystically describing the simplicity of childhood.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:36
verses.text: For sometimes He calls us children, sometimes chickens, sometimes infants, and at other times sons, and "a new people," and "a recent people".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:37
verses.text: "And my servants shall be called by a new name" (a new name, He says, fresh and eternal, pure and simple, and childlike and true), which shall be blessed on the earth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:38
verses.text: And again, He figuratively calls us colts unyoked to vice, not broken in by wickedness; but simple, and bounding joyously to the Father alone; not such horses "as neigh after their neighbours' wives,  that are under the yoke, and are female-mad;" but free and new-born, jubilant by means of faith, ready to run to the truth, swift to speed to salvation, that tread and stamp under foot the things of the world.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:39
verses.text: "Rejoice greatly, O daughter of Sion; tell aloud, O daughter of Jerusalem: behold, thy King cometh, just, meek, and bringing salvation; meek truly is He, and riding on a beast of burden, and a young colt".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:40
verses.text: It was not enough to have said colt alone, but He added to it also young, to show the youth of humanity in Christ, and the eternity of simplicity, which shall know no old age.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:41
verses.text: And we who are little ones being such colts, are reared up by our divine colt-tamer.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:42
verses.text: But if the new man in Scripture is represented by the ass, this ass is also a colt.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:43
verses.text: "And he bound," it is said, "the colt to the vine," having bound this simple and childlike people to the word, whom He figuratively represents as a vine.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:44
verses.text: For the vine produces wine, as the Word produces blood, and both drink for health to men—wine for the body, blood for the spirit.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:45
verses.text: And that He also calls us lambs, the Spirit by the mouth of Isaiah is an unimpeachable witness: "He will feed His flock like a shepherd, He will gather the lambs with His arm,"—using the figurative appellation of lambs, which are still more tender than sheep, to express simplicity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:46
verses.text: And we also in truth, honouring the fairest and most perfect objects in life with an appellation derived from the word child, have named training παιδεία, and discipline παιδαγωγία.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:47
verses.text: Discipline (παιδαγωγία) we declare to be right guiding from childhood to virtue.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:48
verses.text: Accordingly, our Lord revealed more distinctly to us what is signified by the appellation of children.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:49
verses.text: On the question arising among the apostles, "which of them should be the greater," Jesus placed a little child in the midst, saying, "Whosoever, shall humble himself as this little child, the same shall be the greater in the kingdom of heaven".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:50
verses.text: He does not then use the appellation of children on account of their very limited amount of understanding from their age, as some have thought.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:51
verses.text: Nor, if He says, "Except ye become as these children, ye shall not enter into the kingdom of God," are His words to be understood as meaning "without learning".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:52
verses.text: We, then, who are infants, no longer roll on the ground, nor creep on the earth like serpents as before, crawling with the whole body about senseless lusts; but, stretching upwards in soul, loosed from the world and our sins, touching the earth on tiptoe so as to appear to be in the world, we pursue holy wisdom, although this seems folly to those whose wits are whetted for wickedness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:53
verses.text: Rightly, then, are those called children who know Him who is God alone as their Father, who are simple, and infants, and guileless, who are lovers of the horns of the unicorns.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:54
verses.text: To those, therefore, that have made progress in the word, He has proclaimed this utterance, bidding them dismiss anxious care of the things of this world, and exhorting them to adhere to the Father alone, in imitation of children.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:55
verses.text: Wherefore also in what follows He says: "Take no anxious thought for the morrow; sufficient unto the day is the evil thereof".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:56
verses.text: Thus He enjoins them to lay aside the cares of this life, and depend on the Father alone.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:57
verses.text: And he who fulfils this commandment is in reality a child and a son to God and to the world,—to the one as deceived, to the other as beloved.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:58
verses.text: And if we have one Master in heaven, as the Scripture says, then by common consent those on the earth will be rightly called disciples.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:59
verses.text: For so is the truth, that perfection is with the Lord, who is always teaching, and infancy and childishness with us, who are always learning.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:60
verses.text: Thus prophecy hath honoured perfection, by applying to it the appellation man.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:61
verses.text: For instance, by David, He says of the devil: "The Lord abhors the man of blood;" he calls him man, as perfect in wickedness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:62
verses.text: And the Lord is called man, because He is perfect in righteousness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:63
verses.text: Directly in point is the instance of the apostle, who says, writing the Corinthians: "For I have espoused you to one man, that I may present you as a chaste virgin to Christ," whether as children or saints, but to the Lord alone.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:64
verses.text: And writing to the Ephesians, he has unfolded in the clearest manner the point in question, speaking to the following effect: "Till we all attain to the unity of the faith, and of the knowledge of God, to a perfect man, to the measure of the stature of the fulness of Christ: that we be no longer children, tossed to and fro by every wind of doctrine, by the craft of men, by their cunning in stratagems of deceit; but, speaking the truth in love, may grow up to Him in all things,"—saying these things in order to the edification of the body of Christ, who is the head and man, the only one perfect in righteousness; and we who are children guarding against the blasts of heresies, which blow to our inflation; and not putting our trust in fathers who teach us otherwise, are then made perfect when we are the church, having received Christ the head.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:65
verses.text: Then it is right to notice, with respect to the appellation of infant (νήπιος), that  τὸ νήπιον is not predicated of the silly: for the silly man is called νηπύτιος: and νήπιος is νεήπιος (since he that is tender-hearted is called ἤπιος), as being one that has newly become gentle and meek in conduct.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:66
verses.text: This the blessed Paul most clearly pointed out when he said, "When we might have been burdensome as the apostles of Christ, we were gentle (ἤπιοι) among you, as a nurse cherisheth her children".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:67
verses.text: The child (νήπιος) is therefore gentle (ἤπιος), and therefore more tender, delicate, and simple, guileless, and destitute of hypocrisy, straightforward and upright in mind, which is the basis of simplicity and truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:68
verses.text: For He says, "Upon whom shall I look, but upon him who is gentle and quiet?" For such is the virgin speech, tender, and free of fraud; whence also a virgin is wont to be called "a tender bride," and a child "tender-hearted".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:69
verses.text: And we are tender who are pliant to the power of persuasion, and are easily drawn to goodness, and are mild, and free of the stain of malice and perverseness, for the ancient race was perverse and hard-hearted; but the band of infants, the new people which we are, is delicate as a child.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:70
verses.text: On account of the hearts of the innocent, the apostle, in the Epistle to the Romans, owns that he rejoices, and furnishes a kind of definition of children, so to speak, when he says, "I would have you wise toward good, but simple towards evil".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:71
verses.text: For the name of child, νήπιος, is not understood by us privatively, though the sons of the grammarians make the νη a privative particle.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:72
verses.text: For if they call us who follow after childhood foolish, see how they utter blasphemy against the Lord, in regarding those as foolish who have betaken themselves to God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:73
verses.text: But if, which is rather the true sense, they themselves understand the designation children of simple ones, we glory in the name.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:74
verses.text: For the new minds, which have newly become wise, which have sprung into being according to the new covenant, are infantile in the old folly.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:75
verses.text: Of late, then, God was known by the coming of Christ: "For no man knoweth God but the Son, and he to whom the Son shall reveal Him".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:76
verses.text: In contradistinction, therefore, to the older people, the new people are called young, having learned the new blessings; and we have the exuberance of life's morning prime in this youth which knows no old age, in which we are always growing to maturity in intelligence, are always young, always mild, always new: for those must necessarily be new, who have become partakers of the new Word.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:77
verses.text: And that which participates in eternity is wont to be assimilated to the incorruptible: so that to us appertains the designation of the age of childhood, a lifelong spring-time, because the truth that is in us, and our habits saturated with the truth, cannot be touched by old age; but Wisdom is ever blooming, ever remains consistent and the same, and never changes.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:78
verses.text: "Their children," it is said, "shall be borne upon their shoulders, and fondled on their knees; as one whom his mother comforteth, so also shall I comfort you".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:79
verses.text: The mother draws the children to herself; and we seek our mother the Church.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:80
verses.text: Whatever is feeble and tender, as needing help on account of its feebleness, is kindly looked on, and is sweet and pleasant, anger changing into help in the case of such: for thus horses' colts, and the little calves of cows, and the lion's whelp, and the stag's fawn, and the child of man, are looked upon with pleasure by their fathers and mothers.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:81
verses.text: Thus also the Father of the universe cherishes affection towards those who have fled to Him; and having begotten them again by His Spirit to the adoption of children, knows them as gentle, and loves those alone, and aids and fights for them; and therefore He bestows on them the name of child.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:82
verses.text: The word Isaac I also connect with child.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:83
verses.text: Isaac means laughter.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:84
verses.text: He was seen sporting with his wife and helpmeet Rebecca by the prying king.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:85
verses.text: The king, whose name was Abimelech, appears to me to represent a supramundane wisdom contemplating the mystery of sport.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:86
verses.text: They interpret Rebecca to mean endurance.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:87
verses.text: O wise sport, laughter also assisted by endurance, and the king as spectator! The spirit of those that are children in Christ, whose lives are ordered in endurance, rejoice.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:88
verses.text: And this is the divine sport.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:89
verses.text: "Such a sport, of his own, Jove sports," says Heraclitus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:90
verses.text: For what other employment is seemly for a wise and perfect man, than to sport and be glad in the endurance of what is good—and, in the administration of what is good, holding festival with God? That which is signified by the prophet may be interpreted differently,—namely, of our rejoicing for salvation, as Isaac.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:91
verses.text: He also, delivered from death, laughed, sporting and rejoicing with his spouse, who was the type of the Helper of our salvation, the Church, to whom the stable name of endurance is given; for this cause surely, because she alone remains to all generations, rejoicing ever, subsisting as she does by the endurance of us believers, who are the members of Christ.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:92
verses.text: And the witness of those that have endured to the end, and the rejoicing on their account, is the mystic sport, and the salvation accompanied with decorous solace which brings us aid.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:93
verses.text: The King, then, who is Christ, beholds from above our laughter, and looking through the window, as the Scripture says, views the thanksgiving, and the blessing, and the rejoicing, and the gladness, and furthermore the endurance which works together with them and their embrace: views His Church, showing only His face, which was wanting to the Church, which is made perfect by her royal Head.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:94
verses.text: And where, then, was the door by which the Lord showed Himself? The flesh by which He was manifested.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:95
verses.text: He is Isaac (for the narrative may be interpreted otherwise), who is a type of the Lord, a child as a son; for he was the son of Abraham, as Christ the Son of God, and a sacrifice as the Lord, but he was not immolated as the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:96
verses.text: Isaac only bore the wood of the sacrifice, as the Lord the wood of the cross.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:97
verses.text: And he laughed mystically, prophesying that the Lord should fill us with joy, who have been redeemed from corruption by the blood of the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:98
verses.text: Isaac did everything but suffer, as was right, yielding the precedence in suffering to the Word.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:99
verses.text: Furthermore, there is an intimation of the divinity of the Lord in His not being slain.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:100
verses.text: For Jesus rose again after His burial, having suffered no harm, like Isaac released from sacrifice.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:101
verses.text: And in defence of the point to be established, I shall adduce another consideration of the greatest weight.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:102
verses.text: The Spirit calls the Lord Himself a child, thus prophesying by Esaias: "Lo, to us a child has been born, to us a son has been given, on whose own shoulder the government shall be; and His name has been called the Angel of great Counsel".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:103
verses.text: Who, then, is this infant child? He according to whose image we are made little children.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:104
verses.text: By the same prophet is declared His greatness: "Wonderful, Counsellor, Mighty God, Everlasting Father, Prince of Peace; that He might fulfil His discipline: and of His peace there shall be no end".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:105
verses.text: O the great God! O the perfect child! The Son in the Father, and the Father in the Son.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:106
verses.text: And how shall not the discipline of this child be perfect, which extends to all, leading as a schoolmaster us as children who are His little ones? He has stretched forth to us those hands of His that are conspicuously worthy of trust.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 4:107
verses.text: To this child additional testimony is borne by John, "the greatest prophet among those born of women:" Behold the Lamb of God!" For since Scripture calls the infant children lambs, it has also called Him—God the Word—who became man for our sakes, and who wished in all points to be made like to us—"the Lamb of God"—Him, namely, that is the Son of God, the child of the Father.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:1
verses.text: Chapter 6—The Name Children Does Not Imply Instruction in Elementary Principles.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:2
verses.text: We have ample means of encountering those who are given to carping.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:3
verses.text: For we are not termed children and infants with reference to the childish and contemptible character of our education, as those who are inflated on account of knowledge have calumniously alleged.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:4
verses.text: Straightway, on our regeneration, we attained that perfection after which we aspired.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:5
verses.text: For we were illuminated, which is to know God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:6
verses.text: He is not then imperfect who knows what is perfect.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:7
verses.text: And do not reprehend me when I profess to know God; for so it was deemed right to speak to the Word, and He is free.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:8
verses.text: For at the moment of the Lord's baptism there sounded a voice from heaven, as a testimony to the Beloved, "Thou art My beloved Son, to-day have I begotten Thee".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:9
verses.text: Let us then ask the wise, Is Christ, begotten to-day, already perfect, or—what were most monstrous—imperfect? If the latter, there is some addition He requires yet to make.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:10
verses.text: But for Him to make any addition to His knowledge is absurd, since He is God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:11
verses.text: For none can be superior to the Word, or the teacher of the only Teacher.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:12
verses.text: Will they not then own, though reluctant, that the perfect Word born of the perfect Father was begotten in perfection, according to oeconomic fore-ordination? And if He was perfect, why was He, the perfect one, baptized? It was necessary, they say, to fulfil the profession that pertained to humanity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:13
verses.text: Most excellent.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:14
verses.text: Well, I assert, simultaneously with His baptism by John, He becomes perfect? Manifestly.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:15
verses.text: He did not then learn anything more from him? Certainly not.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:16
verses.text: But He is perfected by the washing—of baptism—alone, and is sanctified by the descent of the Spirit? Such is the case.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:17
verses.text: The same also takes place in our case, whose exemplar Christ became.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:18
verses.text: Being baptized, we are illuminated; illuminated, we become sons; being made sons, we are made perfect; being made perfect, we are made immortal.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:19
verses.text: "I," says He, "have said that ye are gods, and all sons of the Highest".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:20
verses.text: This work is variously called grace, and illumination, and perfection, and washing: washing, by which we cleanse away our sins; grace, by which the penalties accruing to transgressions are remitted; and illumination, by which that holy light of salvation is beheld, that is, by which we see God clearly.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:21
verses.text: Now we call that perfect which wants nothing.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:22
verses.text: For what is yet wanting to him who knows God? For it were truly monstrous that that which is not complete should be called a gift (or act) of God's grace.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:23
verses.text: Being perfect, He consequently bestows perfect gifts.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:24
verses.text: As at  His command all things were made, so on His bare wishing to bestow grace, ensues the perfecting of His grace.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:25
verses.text: For the future of time is anticipated by the power of His volition.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:26
verses.text: Further release from evils is the beginning of salvation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:27
verses.text: We then alone, who first have touched the confines of life, are already perfect; and we already live who are separated from death.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:28
verses.text: Salvation, accordingly, is the following of Christ: "For that which is in Him is life.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:29
verses.text: "Verily, verily, I say unto you, He that heareth My words, and believeth on Him that sent Me, hath eternal life, and cometh not into condemnation, but hath passed from death to life".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:30
verses.text: Thus believing alone, and regeneration, is perfection in life; for God is never weak.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:31
verses.text: For as His will is work, and this is named the world; so also His counsel is the salvation of men, and this has been called the church.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:32
verses.text: He knows, therefore, whom He has called, and whom He has saved; and at one and the same time He called and saved them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:33
verses.text: "For ye are," says the apostle, "taught of God".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:34
verses.text: It is not then allowable to think of what is taught by Him as imperfect; and what is learned from Him is the eternal salvation of the eternal Saviour, to whom be thanks for ever and ever, Amen.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:35
verses.text: And he who is only regenerated—as the name necessarily indicates—and is enlightened, is delivered forthwith from darkness, and on the instant receives the light.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:36
verses.text: As, then, those who have shaken off sleep forthwith become all awake within; or rather, as those who try to remove a film that is over the eyes, do not supply to them from without the light which they do not possess, but removing the obstacle from the eyes, leave the pupil free; thus also we who are baptized, having wiped off the sins which obscure the light of the Divine Spirit, have the eye of the spirit free, unimpeded, and full of light, by which alone we contemplate the Divine, the Holy Spirit flowing down to us from above.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:37
verses.text: This is the eternal adjustment of the vision, which is able to see the eternal light, since like loves like; and that which is holy, loves that from which holiness proceeds, which has appropriately been termed light.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:38
verses.text: "Once ye were darkness, now are ye light in the Lord".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:39
verses.text: Hence I am of opinion man was called by the ancients φώς.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:40
verses.text: But he has not yet received, say they, the perfect gift.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:41
verses.text: I also assent to this; but he is in the light, and the darkness comprehendeth him not.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:42
verses.text: There is nothing intermediate between light and darkness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:43
verses.text: But the end is reserved till the resurrection of those who believe; and it is not the reception of some other thing, but the obtaining of the promise previously made.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:44
verses.text: For we do not say that both take place together at the same time—both the arrival at the end, and the anticipation of that arrival.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:45
verses.text: For eternity and time are not the same, neither is the attempt and the final result; but both have reference to the same thing, and one and the same person is concerned in both.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:46
verses.text: Faith, so to speak, is the attempt generated in time; the final result is the attainment of the promise, secured for eternity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:47
verses.text: Now the Lord Himself has most clearly revealed the equality of salvation, when He said: "For this is the will of my Father, that every one that seeth the Son, and believeth on Him, should have everlasting life; and I will raise him up in the last day".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:48
verses.text: As far as possible in this world, which is what he means by the last day, and which is preserved till the time that it shall end, we believe that we are made perfect.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:49
verses.text: Wherefore He says, "He that believeth on the Son hath everlasting life".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:50
verses.text: If, then, those who have believed have life, what remains beyond the possession of eternal life? Nothing is wanting to faith, as it is perfect and complete in itself.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:51
verses.text: If aught is wanting to it, it is not wholly perfect.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:52
verses.text: But faith is not lame in any respect; nor after our departure from this world does it make us who have believed, and received without distinction the earnest of future good, wait; but having in anticipation grasped by faith that which is future, after the resurrection we receive it as present, in order that that may be fulfilled which was spoken, "Be it according to thy faith".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:53
verses.text: And where faith is, there is the promise; and the consummation of the promise is rest.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:54
verses.text: So that in illumination what we receive is knowledge, and the end of knowledge is rest—the last thing conceived as the object of aspiration.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:55
verses.text: As, then, inexperience comes to an end by experience, and perplexity by finding a clear outlet, so by illumination must darkness disappear.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:56
verses.text: The darkness is ignorance, through which we fall into sins, purblind as to the truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:57
verses.text: Knowledge, then, is the illumination we receive, which makes ignorance disappear, and endows us with clear vision.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:58
verses.text: Further, the abandonment of what is bad is the adopting of what is better.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:59
verses.text: For what ignorance has bound ill, is by knowledge loosed well; those bonds are with all speed slackened by human faith and divine grace, our transgressions being taken away by one Poeonian medicine, the baptism of the Word.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:60
verses.text: We are washed from all our sins, and are no longer entangled in evil.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:61
verses.text: This is the one grace of illumination,  that our characters are not the same as before our washing.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:62
verses.text: And since knowledge springs up with illumination, shedding its beams around the mind, the moment we hear, we who were untaught become disciples.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:63
verses.text: Does this, I ask, take place on the advent of this instruction? You cannot tell the time.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:64
verses.text: For instruction leads to faith, and faith with baptism is trained by the Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:65
verses.text: For that faith is the one universal salvation of humanity, and that there is the same equality before the righteous and loving God, and the same fellowship between Him and all, the apostle most clearly showed, speaking to the following effect: "Before faith came, we were kept under the law, shut up unto the faith which should afterwards be revealed, so that the law became our schoolmaster to bring us to Christ, that we might be justified by faith; but after that faith is come, we are no longer under a schoolmaster".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:66
verses.text: Do you not hear that we are no longer under that law which was accompanied with fear, but under the Word, the master of free choice? Then he subjoined the utterance, clear of all partiality: "For ye are all the children of God through faith in Christ Jesus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:67
verses.text: For as many as were baptized into Christ have put on Christ.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:68
verses.text: There is neither Jew nor Greek, there is neither bond nor free, there is neither male nor female: for ye are all one in Christ Jesus".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:69
verses.text: There are not, then, in the same Word some "illuminated (gnostics); and some animal (or natural) men;" but all who have abandoned the desires of the flesh are equal and spiritual before the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:70
verses.text: And again he writes in another place: "For by one spirit are we all baptized into one body, whether Jews or Greeks, whether bond or free, and we have all drunk of one cup".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:71
verses.text: Nor were it absurd to employ the expressions of those who call the reminiscence of better things the filtration of the spirit, understanding by filtration the separation of what is baser, that results from the reminiscence of what is better.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:72
verses.text: There follows of necessity, in him who has come to the recollection of what is better, repentance for what is worse.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:73
verses.text: Accordingly, they confess that the spirit in repentance retraces its steps.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:74
verses.text: In the same way, therefore, we also, repenting of our sins, renouncing our iniquities, purified by baptism, speed back to the eternal light, children to the Father.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:75
verses.text: Jesus therefore, rejoicing in the spirit, said: "I thank Thee, O Father, God of heaven and earth, that Thou hast hid these things from the wise and prudent, and hast revealed them to babes;" the Master and Teacher applying the name babes to us, who are readier to embrace salvation than the wise in the world, who, thinking themselves wise, are inflated with pride.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:76
verses.text: And He exclaims in exultation and exceeding joy, as if lisping with the children, "Even so, Father; for so it seemed good in Thy sight".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:77
verses.text: Wherefore those things which have been concealed from the wise and prudent of this present world have been revealed to babes.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:78
verses.text: Truly, then, are we the children of God, who have put aside the old man, and stripped off the garment of wickedness, and put on the immortality of Christ; that we may become a new, holy people by regeneration, and may keep the man undefiled.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:79
verses.text: And a babe, as God's little one, is cleansed from fornication and wickedness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:80
verses.text: With the greatest clearness the blessed Paul has solved for us this question in his First Epistle to the Corinthians, writing thus: "Brethren, be not children in understanding; howbeit in malice be children, but in understanding be men".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:81
verses.text: And the expression, "When I was a child, I thought as a child, I spake as a child," points out his mode of life according to the law, according to which, thinking childish things, he persecuted, and speaking childish things he blasphemed the Word, not as having yet attained to the simplicity of childhood, but as being in its folly; for the word νήπιον has two meanings.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:82
verses.text: "When I became a man," again Paul says, "I put away childish things".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:83
verses.text: It is not incomplete size of stature, nor a definite measure of time, nor additional secret teachings in things that are manly and more perfect, that the apostle, who himself professes to be a preacher of childishness, alludes to when he sends it, as it were, into banishment; but he applies the name "children" to those who are under the law, who are terrified by fear as children are by bugbears; and "men" to us who are obedient to the Word and masters of ourselves, who have believed, and are saved by voluntary choice, and are rationally, not irrationally, frightened by terror.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:84
verses.text: Of this the apostle himself shall testify, calling as he does the Jews heirs according to the first covenant, and us heirs according to promise: "Now I say, as long as the heir is a child, he differeth nothing from a servant, though he be lord of all; but is under tutors and governors, till the time appointed by the father.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:85
verses.text: So also we, when we were children, were in bondage under the rudiments of the world: but when the fulness of the time was come, God sent forth His Son, made of a woman, made under the law, to redeem them that were under the law, that we might receive the adoption of sons" by Him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:86
verses.text: See how He has admitted those to be children who are under fear and sins; but has conferred manhood on those who are under faith, by calling them sons, in contradistinction from the children that are under the law: "For thou art no more a servant," he says, "but a son; and if a son, then an heir through God".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:87
verses.text: What, then, is lacking to the son after inheritance? Wherefore the expression, "When I was a child," may be elegantly expounded thus: that is, when I was a Jew (for he was a Hebrew by extraction) I thought as a child, when I followed the law; but after becoming a man, I no longer entertain the sentiments of a child, that is, of the law, but of a man, that is, of Christ, whom alone the Scripture calls man, as we have said before.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:88
verses.text: "I put away childish things".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:89
verses.text: But the childhood which is in Christ is maturity, as compared with the law.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:90
verses.text: Having reached this point, we must defend our childhood.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:91
verses.text: And we have still to explain what is said by the apostle: "I have fed you with milk (as children in Christ), not with meat; for ye were not able, neither yet are ye now able".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:92
verses.text: For it does not appear to me that the expression is to be taken in a Jewish sense; for I shall oppose to it also that Scripture, "I will bring you into that good land which flows with milk and honey".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:93
verses.text: A very great difficulty arises in reference to the comparison of these Scriptures, when we consider.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:94
verses.text: For if the infancy which is characterized by the milk is the beginning of faith in Christ, then it is disparaged as childish and imperfect.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:95
verses.text: How is the rest that comes after the meat, the rest of the man who is perfect and endowed with knowledge, again distinguished by infant milk? Does not this, as explaining a parable, mean something like this, and is not the expression to be read somewhat to the following effect: "I have fed you with milk in Christ;" and after a slight stop, let us add, "as children," that by separating the words in reading we may make out some such sense as this: I have instructed you in Christ with simple, true, and natural nourishment,—namely, that which is spiritual: for such is the nourishing substance of milk swelling out from breasts of love.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:96
verses.text: So that the whole matter may be conceived thus: As nurses nourish new-born children on milk, so do I also by the Word, the milk of Christ, instilling into you spiritual nutriment.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:97
verses.text: Thus, then, the milk which is perfect is perfect nourishment, and brings to that consummation which cannot cease.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:98
verses.text: Wherefore also the same milk and honey were promised in the rest.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:99
verses.text: Rightly, therefore, the Lord again promises milk to the righteous, that the Word may be clearly shown to be both, "the Alpha and Omega, beginning and end;" the Word being figuratively represented as milk.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:100
verses.text: Something like this Homer oracularly declares against his will, when he calls righteous men milk-fed (γαλακτοφάγοι).

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:101
verses.text: So also may we take the Scripture: "And I, brethren, could not speak unto you as unto spiritual, but as unto carnal, even as unto babes in Christ;" so that the carnal may be understood as those recently instructed, and still babes in Christ.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:102
verses.text: For he called those who had already believed on the Holy Spirit spiritual, and those newly instructed and not yet purified carnal; whom with justice he calls still carnal, as minding equally with the heathen the things of the flesh: "For whereas there is among you envy and strife, are ye not carnal, and walk as men?" "Wherefore also I have given you milk to drink," he says; meaning, I have instilled into you the knowledge which, from instruction, nourishes up to life eternal.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:103
verses.text: But the expression, "I have given you to drink" (ἐπότισα), is the symbol of perfect appropriation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:104
verses.text: For those who are full-grown are said to drink, babes to suck.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:105
verses.text: "For my blood," says the Lord, "is true drink".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:106
verses.text: In saying, therefore, "I have given you milk to drink," has he not indicated the knowledge of the truth, the perfect gladness in the Word, who is the milk? And what follows next, "not meat, for ye were not able," may indicate the clear revelation in the future world, like food, face to face.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:107
verses.text: "For now we see as through a glass," the same apostle says, "but then face to face".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:108
verses.text: Wherefore also he has added, "neither yet are ye now able, for ye are still carnal," minding the things of the flesh,—desiring, loving, feeling jealousy, wrath, envy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:109
verses.text: "For we are no more in the flesh," as some suppose.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:110
verses.text: For with it they say, having the face which is like an angel's, we shall see the promise face to face.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:111
verses.text: How then, if that is truly the promise after our departure hence, say they that they know "what eye hath not known, nor hath entered into the mind of man," who have not perceived by the Spirit, but received from instruction "what ear hath not heard," or that ear alone which "was rapt up into the third heaven?" But it even then was commanded to preserve it unspoken.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:112
verses.text: But if human wisdom, as it remains to understand, is the glorying in knowledge, hear the law  of Scripture: "Let not the wise man glory in his wisdom, and let not the mighty man glory in his might; but let him that glorieth glory in the Lord".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:113
verses.text: But we are God-taught, and glory in the name of Christ.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:114
verses.text: How then are we not to regard the apostle as attaching this sense to the milk of the babes? And if we who preside over the Churches are shepherds after the image of the good Shepherd, and you the sheep, are we not to regard the Lord as preserving consistency in the use of figurative speech, when He speaks also of the milk of the flock? And to this meaning we may secondly accommodate the expression, "I have given you milk to drink, and not given you food, for ye are not yet able," regarding the meat not as something different from the milk, but the same in substance.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:115
verses.text: For the very same Word is fluid and mild as milk, or solid and compact as meat.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:116
verses.text: And entertaining this view, we may regard the proclamation of the Gospel, which is universally diffused, as milk; and as meat, faith, which from instruction is compacted into a foundation, which, being more substantial than hearing, is likened to meat, and assimilates to the soul itself nourishment of this kind.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:117
verses.text: Elsewhere the Lord, in the Gospel according to John, brought this out by symbols, when He said: "Eat ye my flesh, and drink my blood;" describing distinctly by metaphor the drinkable properties of faith and the promise, by means of which the Church, like a human being consisting of many members, is refreshed and grows, is welded together and compacted of both,—of faith, which is the body, and of hope, which is the soul; as also the Lord of flesh and blood.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:118
verses.text: For in reality the blood of faith is hope, in which faith is held as by a vital principle.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:119
verses.text: And when hope expires, it is as if blood flowed forth; and the vitality of faith is destroyed.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:120
verses.text: If, then, some would oppose, saying that by milk is meant the first lessons—as it were, the first food—and that by meat is meant those spiritual cognitions to which they attain by raising themselves to knowledge, let them understand that, in saying that meat is solid food, and the flesh and blood of Jesus, they are brought by their own vainglorious wisdom to the true simplicity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:121
verses.text: For the blood is found to be an original product in man, and some have consequently ventured to call it the substance of the soul.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:122
verses.text: And this blood, transmuted by a natural process of assimilation in the pregnancy of the mother, through the sympathy of parental affection, effloresces and grows old, in order that there may be no fear for the child.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:123
verses.text: Blood, too, is the moister part of flesh, being a kind of liquid flesh; and milk is the sweeter and finer part of blood.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:124
verses.text: For whether it be the blood supplied to the foetus, and sent through the navel of the mother, or whether it be the menses themselves shut out from their proper passage, and by a natural diffusion, bidden by the all-nourishing and creating God, proceed to the already swelling breasts, and by the heat of the spirits transmuted, whether it be the one or the other that is formed into food desirable for the babe, that which is changed is the blood.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:125
verses.text: For of all the members, the breasts have the most sympathy with the womb.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:126
verses.text: When there is parturition, the vessel by which blood was conveyed to the foetus is cut off: there is an obstruction of the flow, and the blood receives an impulse towards the breasts; and on a considerable rush taking place, they are distended, and change the blood to milk in a manner analogous to the change of blood into pus in ulceration.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:127
verses.text: Or if, on the other hand, the blood from the veins in the vicinity of the breasts, which have been opened in pregnancy, is poured into the natural hollows of the breasts; and the spirit discharged from the neighbouring arteries being mixed with it, the substance of the blood, still remaining pure, it becomes white by being agitated like a wave; and by an interruption such as this is changed by frothing it, like what takes place with the sea, which at the assaults of the winds, the poets say, "spits forth briny foam".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:128
verses.text: Yet still the essence is supplied by the blood.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:129
verses.text: In this way also the rivers, borne on with rushing motion, and fretted by contact with the surrounding air, murmur forth foam.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:130
verses.text: The moisture in our mouth, too, is whitened by the breath.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:131
verses.text: What an absurdity is it, then, not to acknowledge that the blood is converted into that very bright and white substance by the breath! The change it suffers is in quality, not in essence.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:132
verses.text: You will certainly find nothing else more nourishing, or sweeter, or whiter than milk.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:133
verses.text: In every respect, accordingly, it is like spiritual nourishment, which is sweet through grace, nourishing as life, bright as the day of Christ.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:134
verses.text: The blood of the Word has been also exhibited as milk.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:135
verses.text: Milk being thus provided in parturition, is supplied to the infant; and the breasts, which till then looked straight towards the husband, now bend down towards the child, being taught to furnish the substance elaborated by nature in a way easily received for salutary nourishment.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:136
verses.text: For the breasts are not like fountains full of milk, flowing in ready prepared; but, by effecting a change in the nutriment, form the milk in themselves, and discharge it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:137
verses.text: And the nutriment suitable and wholesome for the new-formed and new-born babe is elaborated by God, the nourisher and the Father of all that are generated and regenerated,—as manna, the celestial food of  angels, flowed down from heaven on the ancient Hebrews.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:138
verses.text: Even now, in fact, nurses call the first-poured drink of milk by the same name as that food—manna.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:139
verses.text: Further, pregnant women, on becoming mothers, discharge milk.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:140
verses.text: But the Lord Christ, the fruit of the Virgin, did not pronounce the breasts of women blessed, nor selected them to give nourishment; but when the kind and loving Father had rained down the Word, Himself became spiritual nourishment to the good.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:141
verses.text: O mystic marvel! The universal Father is one, and one the universal Word; and the Holy Spirit is one and the same everywhere, and one is the only virgin mother.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:142
verses.text: I love to call her the Church.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:143
verses.text: This mother, when alone, had not milk, because alone she was not a woman.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:144
