verses.text: But she is once virgin and mother—pure as a virgin, loving as a mother.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:145
verses.text: And calling her children to her, she nurses them with holy milk, viz.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:146
verses.text: , with the Word for childhood.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:147
verses.text: Therefore she had not milk; for the milk was this child fair and comely, the body of Christ, which nourishes by the Word the young brood, which the Lord Himself brought forth in throes of the flesh, which the Lord Himself swathed in His precious blood.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:148
verses.text: O amazing birth! O holy swaddling bands! The Word is all to the child, both father and mother and tutor and nurse.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:149
verses.text: "Eat ye my flesh," He says, "and drink my blood".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:150
verses.text: Such is the suitable food which the Lord ministers, and He offers His flesh and pours forth His blood, and nothing is wanting for the children's growth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:151
verses.text: O amazing mystery! We are enjoined to cast off the old and carnal corruption, as also the old nutriment, receiving in exchange another new regimen, that of Christ, receiving Him if we can, to hide Him within; and that, enshrining the Saviour in our souls, we may correct the affections of our flesh.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:152
verses.text: But you are not inclined to understand it thus, but perchance more generally.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:153
verses.text: Hear it also in the following way.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:154
verses.text: The flesh figuratively represents to us the Holy Spirit; for the flesh was created by Him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:155
verses.text: The blood points out to us the Word, for as rich blood the Word has been infused into life; and the union of both is the Lord, the food of the babes—the Lord who is Spirit and Word.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:156
verses.text: The food—that is, the Lord Jesus—that is, the Word of God, the Spirit made flesh, the heavenly flesh sanctified.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:157
verses.text: The nutriment is the milk of the Father, by which alone we infants are nourished.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:158
verses.text: The Word Himself, then, the beloved One, and our nourisher, hath shed His own blood for us, to save humanity; and by Him, we, believing on God, flee to the Word, "the care-soothing breast" of the Father.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:159
verses.text: And He alone, as is befitting, supplies us children with the milk of love, and those only are truly blessed who suck this breast.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:160
verses.text: Wherefore also Peter says: "Laying therefore aside all malice, and all guile, and hypocrisy, and envy, and evil speaking, as new-born babes, desire the milk of the word, that ye may grow by it to salvation; if ye have tasted that the Lord is Christ".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:161
verses.text: And were one to concede to them that the meat was something different from the milk, then how shall they avoid being transfixed on their own spit, through want of consideration of nature? For in winter, when the air is condensed, and prevents the escape of the heat enclosed within, the food, transmuted and digested and changed into blood, passes into the veins, and these, in the absence of exhalation, are greatly distended, and exhibit strong pulsations; consequently also nurses are then fullest of milk.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:162
verses.text: And we have shown a little above, that on pregnancy blood passes into milk by a change which does not affect its substance, just as in old people yellow hair changes to grey.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:163
verses.text: But again in summer, the body, having its pores more open, affords greater facility for diaphoretic action in the case of the food, and the milk is least abundant, since neither is the blood full, nor is the whole nutriment retained.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:164
verses.text: If, then, the digestion of the food results in the production of blood, and the blood becomes milk, then blood is a preparation for milk, as blood is for a human beings, and the grape for the vine.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:165
verses.text: With milk, then, the Lord's nutriment, we are nursed directly we are born; and as soon as we are regenerated, we are honoured by receiving the good news of the hope of rest, even the Jerusalem above, in which it is written that milk and honey fall in showers, receiving through what is material the pledge of the sacred food.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:166
verses.text: "For meats are done away with," as the apostle himself says; but this nourishment on milk leads to the heavens, rearing up citizens of heaven, and members of the angelic choirs.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:167
verses.text: And since the Word is the gushing fountain of life, and has been called a river of olive oil, Paul, using appropriate figurative language, and calling Him milk, adds: "I have given you to drink;" for we drink in the word, the nutriment of the truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:168
verses.text: In truth, also liquid food is called drink; and the same thing may somehow be both meat and drink, according to the different aspects in which it is considered, just as cheese is the solidification of milk or milk solidified; for I am not concerned here to make a nice selection of an expression, only to say that one substance supplies both articles of food.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:169
verses.text: Besides, for children at the breast, milk alone suffices; it serves both for meat and drink.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:170
verses.text: "I,"  says the Lord, "have meat to eat that ye know not of.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:171
verses.text: My meat is to do the will of Him that sent Me".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:172
verses.text: You see another kind of food which, similarly with milk, represents figuratively the will of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:173
verses.text: Besides, also, the completion of His own passion He called catachrestically "a cup," when He alone had to drink and drain it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:174
verses.text: Thus to Christ the fulfilling of His Father's will was food; and to us infants, who drink the milk of the word of the heavens, Christ Himself is food.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:175
verses.text: Hence seeking is called sucking; for to those babes that seek the Word, the Father's breasts of love supply milk.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:176
verses.text: Further, the Word declares Himself to be the bread of heaven.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:177
verses.text: "For Moses," He says, "gave you not that bread from heaven, but My Father giveth you the true bread from heaven.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:178
verses.text: For the bread of God is He that cometh down from heaven, and giveth life to the world.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:179
verses.text: And the bread which I will give is My flesh, which I will give for the life of the world".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:180
verses.text: Here is to be noted the mystery of the bread, inasmuch as He speaks of it as flesh, and as flesh, consequently, that has risen through fire, as the wheat springs up from decay and germination; and, in truth, it has risen through fire for the joy of the Church, as bread baked.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:181
verses.text: But this will be shown by and by more clearly in the chapter on the resurrection.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:182
verses.text: But since He said, "And the bread which I will give is My flesh," and since flesh is moistened with blood, and blood is figuratively termed wine, we are bidden to know that, as bread, crumbled into a mixture of wine and water, seizes on the wine and leaves the watery portion, so also the flesh of Christ, the bread of heaven absorbs the blood; that is, those among men who are heavenly, nourishing them up to immortality, and leaving only to destruction the lusts of the flesh.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:183
verses.text: Thus in many ways the Word is figuratively described, as meat, and flesh, and food, and bread, and blood, and milk.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:184
verses.text: The Lord is all these, to give enjoyment to us who have believed on Him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:185
verses.text: Let no one then think it strange, when we say that the Lord's blood is figuratively represented as milk.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:186
verses.text: For is it not figuratively represented as wine? "Who washes," it is said, "His garment in wine, His robe in the blood of the grape".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:187
verses.text: In His own Spirit He says He will deck the body of the Word; as certainly by His own Spirit He will nourish those who hunger for the Word.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:188
verses.text: And that the blood is the Word, is testified by the blood of Abel, the righteous interceding with God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:189
verses.text: For the blood would never have uttered a voice, had it not been regarded as the Word: for the righteous man of old is the type of the new righteous one; and the blood of old that interceded, intercedes in the place of the new blood.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:190
verses.text: And the blood that is the Word cries to God, since it intimated that the Word was to suffer.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:191
verses.text: Further, this flesh, and the blood in it, are by a mutual sympathy moistened and increased by the milk.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:192
verses.text: And the process of formation of the seed in conception ensues when it has mingled with the pure residue of the menses, which remains.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:193
verses.text: For the force that is in the seed coagulating the substances of the blood, as the rennet curdles milk, effects the essential part of the formative process.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:194
verses.text: For a suitable blending conduces to fruitfulness; but extremes are adverse, and tend to sterility.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:195
verses.text: For when the earth itself is flooded by excessive rain, the seed is swept away, while in consequence of scarcity it is dried up; but when the sap is viscous, it retains the seed, and makes it germinate.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:196
verses.text: Some also hold the hypothesis, that the seed of an animal is in substance the foam of the blood, which being by the natural heat of the male agitated and shaken out is turned into foam, and deposited in the seminal veins.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:197
verses.text: For Diogenes Apollionates will have it, that hence is derived the word aphrodisia.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:198
verses.text: From all this it is therefore evident, that the essential principle of the human body is blood.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:199
verses.text: The contents of the stomach, too, at first are milky, a coagulation of fluid; then the same coagulated substance is changed into blood; but when it is formed into a compact consistency in the womb, by the natural and warm spirit by which the embryo is fashioned, it becomes a living creature.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:200
verses.text: Further also, the child after birth is nourished by the same blood.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:201
verses.text: For the flow of milk is the product of the blood; and the source of nourishment is the milk; by which a woman is shown to have brought forth a child, and to be truly a mother, by which also she receives a potent charm of affection.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:202
verses.text: Wherefore the Holy Spirit in the apostle, using the voice of the Lord, says mystically, "I have given you milk to drink".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:203
verses.text: For if we have been regenerated unto Christ, He who has regenerated us nourishes us with His own milk, the Word; for it is proper that what has procreated should forthwith supply nourishment to that which has been procreated.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:204
verses.text: And as the regeneration was conformably spiritual, so also was the nutriment of man spiritual.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:205
verses.text: In all respects, therefore, and in all things, we are brought into union with Christ, into relationship through His blood, by which we are redeemed; and into sympathy, in consequence of the nourishment which flows from  the Word; and into immortality, through His guidance:—  "Among men the bringing up of children Often produces stronger impulses to love than the procreating of them".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:206
verses.text: The same blood and milk of the Lord is therefore the symbol of the Lord's passion and teaching.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:207
verses.text: Wherefore each of us babes is permitted to make our boast in the Lord, while we proclaim:—  "Yet of a noble sire and noble blood I boast me sprung".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:208
verses.text: And that milk is produced from blood by a change, is already clear; yet we may learn it from the flocks and herds.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:209
verses.text: For these animals, in the time of the year which we call spring, when the air has more humidity, and the grass and meadows are juicy and moist, are first filled with blood, as is shown by the distension of the veins of the swollen vessels; and from the blood the milk flows more copiously.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:210
verses.text: But in summer again, the blood being burnt and dried up by the heat, prevents the change, and so they have less milk.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:211
verses.text: Further, milk has a most natural affinity for water, as assuredly the spiritual washing has for the spiritual nutriment.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:212
verses.text: Those, therefore, that swallow a little cold water, in addition to the above-mentioned milk, straightway feel benefit; for the milk is prevented from souring by its combination with water, not in consequence of any antipathy between them, but in consequence of the water taking kindly to the milk while it is undergoing digestion.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:213
verses.text: And such as is the union of the Word with baptism, is the agreement of milk with water; for it receives it alone of all liquids, and admits of mixture with water, for the purpose of cleansing, as baptism for the remission of sins.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:214
verses.text: And it is mixed naturally with honey also, and this for cleansing along with sweet nutriment.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:215
verses.text: For the Word blended with love at once cures our passions and cleanses our sins; and the saying,  "Sweeter than honey flowed the stream of speech,"  seems to me to have been spoken of the Word, who is honey.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:216
verses.text: And prophecy oft extols Him "above honey and the honeycomb".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:217
verses.text: Furthermore, milk is mixed with sweet wine; and the mixture is beneficial, as when suffering is mixed in the cup in order to immortality.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:218
verses.text: For the milk is curdled by the wine, and separated, and whatever adulteration is in it is drained off.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:219
verses.text: And in the same way, the spiritual communion of faith with suffering man, drawing off as serous matter the lusts of the flesh, commits man to eternity, along with those who are divine, immortalizing him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:220
verses.text: Further, many also use the fat of milk, called butter, for the lamp, plainly indicating by this enigma the abundant unction of the Word, since He alone it is who nourishes the infants, makes them grow, and enlightens them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:221
verses.text: Wherefore also the Scripture says respecting the Lord, "He fed them with the produce of the fields; they sucked honey from the rock, and oil from the solid rock, butter of kine, and milk of sheep, with fat of lambs;" and what follows He gave them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:222
verses.text: But he that prophesies the birth of the child says: "Butter and honey shall He eat".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:223
verses.text: And it occurs to me to wonder how some dare call themselves perfect and gnostics, with ideas of themselves above the apostle, inflated and boastful, when Paul even owned respecting himself, "Not that I have already attained, or am already perfect; but I follow after, if that I may apprehend that for which I am apprehended of Christ.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:224
verses.text: Brethren, I count not myself to have apprehended: but this one thing I do, forgetting the things which are behind, and stretching forth to those that are before, I press toward the mark, for the prize of the high calling in Christ Jesus".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:225
verses.text: And yet he reckons himself perfect, because he has been emancipated from his former life, and strives after the better life, not as perfect in knowledge, but as aspiring after perfection.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 5:226
verses.text: Wherefore also he adds, "As many of us as are perfect, are thus minded," manifestly describing perfection as the renunciation of sin, and regeneration into the faith of the only perfect One, and forgetting our former sins.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:1
verses.text: Chapter 7—Who the Instructor Is, and Respecting His Instruction.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:2
verses.text: Since, then, we have shown that all of us are by Scripture called children; and not only so, but that we who have followed Christ are figuratively called babes; and that the Father of all alone is perfect, for the Son is in Him, and the Father is in the Son; it is time for us in due course to say who our Instructor is.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:3
verses.text: He is called Jesus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:4
verses.text: Sometimes He calls Himself a shepherd, and says, "I am the good Shepherd".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:5
verses.text: According to a metaphor drawn from shepherds, who lead the sheep, is hereby understood the Instructor, who leads the children—the Shepherd who tends the babes.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:6
verses.text: For the babes are simple, being figuratively described as sheep.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:7
verses.text: "And they shall all," it is said, "be one flock, and one shepherd".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:8
verses.text: The Word, then,  who leads the children to salvation, is appropriately called the Instructor (Paedagogue).

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:9
verses.text: With the greatest clearness, accordingly, the Word has spoken respecting Himself by Hosea: "I am your Instructor".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:10
verses.text: Now piety is instruction, being the learning of the service of God, and training in the knowledge of the truth, and right guidance which leads to heaven.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:11
verses.text: And the word "instruction" is employed variously.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:12
verses.text: For there is the instruction of him who is led and learns, and that of him who leads and teaches; and there is, thirdly, the guidance itself; and fourthly, what is taught, as the commandments enjoined.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:13
verses.text: Now the instruction which is of God is the right direction of truth to the contemplation of God, and the exhibition of holy deeds in everlasting perseverance.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:14
verses.text: As therefore the general directs the phalanx, consulting the safety of his soldiers, and the pilot steers the vessel, desiring to save the passengers; so also the Instructor guides the children to a saving course of conduct, through solicitude for us; and, in general, whatever we ask in accordance with reason from God to be done for us, will happen to those who believe in the Instructor.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:15
verses.text: And just as the helmsman does not always yield to the winds, but sometimes, turning the prow towards them, opposes the whole force of the hurricanes; so the Instructor never yields to the blasts that blow in this world, nor commits the child to them like a vessel to make shipwreck on a wild and licentious course of life; but, wafted on by the favouring breeze of the Spirit of truth, stoutly holds on to the child's helm,—his ears, I mean,—until He bring him safe to anchor in the haven of heaven.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:16
verses.text: What is called by men an ancestral custom passes away in a moment, but the divine guidance is a possession which abides for ever.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:17
verses.text: They say that Phoenix was the instructor of Achilles, and Adrastus of the children of Croesus; and Leonides of Alexander, and Nausithous of Philip.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:18
verses.text: But Phoenix was women-mad, Adrastus was a fugitive.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:19
verses.text: Leonides did not curtail the pride of Alexander, nor Nausithous reform the drunken Pellaean.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:20
verses.text: No more was the Thracian Zopyrus able to check the fornication of Alcibiades; but Zopyrus was a bought slave, and Sicinnus, the tutor of the children of Themistocles, was a lazy domestic.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:21
verses.text: They say also that he invented the Sicinnian dance.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:22
verses.text: Those have not escaped our attention who are called royal instructors among the Persians; whom, in number four, the kings of the Persians select with the greatest care from all the Persians and set over their sons.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:23
verses.text: But the children only learn the use of the bow, and on reaching maturity have sexual intercourse with sisters, and mothers, and women, wives and courtesans innumerable, practiced in intercourse like the wild boars.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:24
verses.text: But our Instructor is the holy God Jesus, the Word, who is the guide of all humanity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:25
verses.text: The loving God Himself is our Instructor.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:26
verses.text: Somewhere in song the Holy Spirit says with regard to Him, "He provided sufficiently for the people in the wilderness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:27
verses.text: He led him about in the thirst of summer heat in a dry land, and instructed him, and kept him as the apple of His eye, as an eagle protects her nest, and shows her fond solicitude for her young, spreads abroad her wings, takes them, and bears them on her back.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:28
verses.text: The Lord alone led them, and there was no strange god with them".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:29
verses.text: Clearly, I trow, has the Scripture exhibited the Instructor in the account it gives of His guidance.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:30
verses.text: Again, when He speaks in His own person, He confesses Himself to be the Instructor: "I am the Lord thy God, who brought thee out of the land of Egypt".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:31
verses.text: Who, then, has the power of leading in and out? Is it not the Instructor? This was He who appeared to Abraham, and said to him, "I am thy God, be accepted before Me;" and in a way most befitting an instructor, forms him into a faithful child, saying, "And be blameless; and I will make My covenant between Me and thee, and thy seed".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:32
verses.text: There is the communication of the Instructor's friendship.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:33
verses.text: And He most manifestly appears as Jacob's instructor.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:34
verses.text: He says accordingly to him, "Lo, I am with thee, to keep thee in all the way in which thou shalt go; and I will bring thee back into this land: for I will not leave thee till I do what I have told thee".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:35
verses.text: He is said, too, to have wrestled with Him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:36
verses.text: "And Jacob was left alone, and there wrestled with him a man (the Instructor) till the morning".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:37
verses.text: This was the man who led, and brought, and wrestled with, and anointed the athlete Jacob against evil.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:38
verses.text: Now that the Word was at once Jacob's trainer and the Instructor of humanity appears from this—"He asked," it is said, "His name, and said to him, Tell me what is Thy name".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:39
verses.text: And he said, "Why is it that thou askest My name?" For He reserved the new name for the new people—the babe; and was as yet unnamed, the Lord God not having yet become man.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:40
verses.text: Yet Jacob called the name of the place, "Face of God".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:41
verses.text: "For I have seen," he says, "God face to face; and my life is preserved".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:42
verses.text: The face of God is the Word by whom God is manifested  and made known.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:43
verses.text: Then also was he named Israel, because he saw God the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:44
verses.text: It was God, the Word, the Instructor, who said to him again afterwards, "Fear not to go down into Egypt".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:45
verses.text: See how the Instructor follows the righteous man, and how He anoints the athlete, teaching him to trip up his antagonist.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:46
verses.text: It is He also who teaches Moses to act as instructor.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:47
verses.text: For the Lord says, "If any one sin before Me, him will I blot out of My book; but now, go and lead this people into the place which I told thee".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:48
verses.text: Here He is the teacher of the art of instruction.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:49
verses.text: For it was really the Lord that was the instructor of the ancient people by Moses; but He is the instructor of the new people by Himself, face to face.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:50
verses.text: "For behold," He says to Moses, "My angel shall go before thee," representing the evangelical and commanding power of the Word, but guarding the Lord's prerogative.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:51
verses.text: "In the day on which I will visit them," He says, "I will bring their sins on them; that is, on the day on which I will sit as judge I will render the recompense of their sins".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:52
verses.text: For the same who is Instructor is judge, and judges those who disobey Him; and the loving Word will not pass over their transgression in silence.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:53
verses.text: He reproves, that they may repent.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:54
verses.text: For "the Lord willeth the repentance of the sinner rather than his death".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:55
verses.text: And let us as babes, hearing of the sins of others, keep from similar transgressions, through dread of the threatening, that we may not have to undergo like sufferings.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:56
verses.text: What, then, was the sin which they committed? "For in their wrath they slew men, and in their impetuosity they hamstrung bulls.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:57
verses.text: Cursed be their anger".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:58
verses.text: Who, then, would train us more lovingly than He? Formerly the older people had an old covenant, and the law disciplined the people with fear, and the Word was an angel; but to the fresh and new people has also been given a new covenant, and the Word has appeared, and fear is turned to love, and that mystic angel is born—Jesus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:59
verses.text: For this same Instructor said then, "Thou shalt fear the Lord God;" but to us He has addressed the exhortation, "Thou shalt love the Lord thy God".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:60
verses.text: Wherefore also this is enjoined on us: "Cease from your own works, from your old sins;" "Learn to do well;" "Depart from evil, and do good;" "Thou hast loved righteousness, and hated iniquity".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:61
verses.text: This is my new covenant written in the old letter.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:62
verses.text: The newness of the word must not, then, be made ground of reproach.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:63
verses.text: But the Lord hath also said in Jeremiah: "Say not that I am a youth: before I formed thee in the belly I knew thee, and before I brought thee out of the womb I sanctified thee".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:64
verses.text: Such allusions prophecy can make to us, destined in the eye of God to faith before the foundation of the world; but now babes, through the recent fulfilment of the will of God, according to which we are born now to calling and salvation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:65
verses.text: Wherefore also He adds, "I have set thee for a prophet to the nations," saying that he must prophesy, so that the appellation of "youth" should not become a reproach to those who are called babes.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:66
verses.text: Now the law is ancient grace given through Moses by the Word.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:67
verses.text: Wherefore also the Scripture says, "The law was given through Moses," not by Moses, but by the Word, and through Moses His servant.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:68
verses.text: Wherefore it was only temporary; but eternal grace and truth were by Jesus Christ.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:69
verses.text: Mark the expressions of Scripture: of the law only is it said "was given;" but truth being the grace of the Father, is the eternal work of the Word; and it is not said to be given, but to be by Jesus, without whom nothing was.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:70
verses.text: Presently, therefore, Moses prophetically, giving place to the perfect Instructor the Word, predicts both the name and the office of Instructor, and committing to the people the commands of obedience, sets before them the Instructor.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:71
verses.text: "A prophet," says he, "like Me shall God raise up to you of your brethren," pointing out Jesus the Son of God, by an allusion to Jesus the son of Nun; for the name of Jesus predicted in the law was a shadow of Christ.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:72
verses.text: He adds, therefore, consulting the advantage of the people, "Him shall ye hear;" and, "The man who will not hear that Prophet," him He threatens.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:73
verses.text: Such a name, then, he predicts as that of the Instructor, who is the author of salvation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:74
verses.text: Wherefore prophecy invests Him with a rod, a rod of discipline, of rule, of authority; that those whom the persuasive word heals not, the threatening may heal; and whom the threatening heals not, the rod may heal; and whom the rod heals not, the fire may devour.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:75
verses.text: "There shall come forth," it is said, "a rod out of the root of Jesse".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:76
verses.text: See the care, and wisdom, and power of the Instructor: "He shall not judge according to opinion, nor according to report; but He shall dispense judgment to the humble, and reprove the sinners of the earth".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:77
verses.text: And by David: "The Lord instructing, hath instructed me, and not given me over to death".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:78
verses.text: For to be chastised of the Lord, and instructed, is deliverance from death.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:79
verses.text: And by the same prophet He says:  "Thou shalt rule them with a rod of iron".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:80
verses.text: Thus also the apostle, in the Epistle to the Corinthians, being moved, says, "What will ye? Shall I come unto you with a rod, or in love, in the spirit of meekness?" Also, "The Lord shall send the rod of strength out of Sion," He says by another prophet.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:81
verses.text: And this same rod of instruction, "Thy rod and staff have comforted me," said some one else.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 6:82
verses.text: Such is the power of the Instructor—sacred, soothing, saving.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:1
verses.text: Chapter 8—Against Those Who Think that What is Just is Not Good.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:2
verses.text: At this stage some rise up, saying that the Lord, by reason of the rod, and threatening, and fear, is not good; misapprehending, as appears, the Scripture which says, "And he that feareth the Lord will turn to his heart;" and most of all, oblivious of His love, in that for us He became man.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:3
verses.text: For more suitably to Him, the prophet prays in these words: "Remember us, for we are dust;" that is, Sympathize with us; for Thou knowest from personal experience of suffering the weakness of the flesh.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:4
verses.text: In this respect, therefore, the Lord the Instructor is most good and unimpeachable, sympathizing as He does from the exceeding greatness of His love with the nature of each man.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:5
verses.text: "For there is nothing which the Lord hates".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:6
verses.text: For assuredly He does not hate anything, and yet wish that which He hates to exist.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:7
verses.text: Nor does He wish anything not to exist, and yet become the cause of existence to that which He wishes not to exist.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:8
verses.text: Nor does He wish anything not to exist which yet exists.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:9
verses.text: If, then, the Word hates anything, He does not wish it to exist.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:10
verses.text: But nothing exists, the cause of whose existence is not supplied by God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:11
verses.text: Nothing, then, is hated by God, nor yet by the Word.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:12
verses.text: For both are one—that is, God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:13
verses.text: For He has said, "In the beginning the Word was in God, and the Word was God".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:14
verses.text: If then He hates none of the things which He has made, it follows that He loves them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:15
verses.text: Much more than the rest, and with reason, will He love man, the noblest of all objects created by Him, and a God-loving being.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:16
verses.text: Therefore God is loving; consequently the Word is loving.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:17
verses.text: But he who loves anything wishes to do it good.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:18
verses.text: And that which does good must be every way better than that which does not good.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:19
verses.text: But nothing is better than the Good.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:20
verses.text: The Good, then, does good.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:21
verses.text: And God is admitted to be good.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:22
verses.text: God therefore does good.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:23
verses.text: And the Good, in virtue of its being good, does nothing else than do good.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:24
verses.text: Consequently God does all good.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:25
verses.text: And He does no good to man without caring for him, and He does not care for him without taking care of him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:26
verses.text: For that which does good purposely, is better than what does not good purposely.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:27
verses.text: But nothing is better than God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:28
verses.text: And to do good purposely, is nothing else than to take care of man.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:29
verses.text: God therefore cares for man, and takes care of him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:30
verses.text: And He shows this practically, in instructing him by the Word, who is the true coadjutor of God's love to man.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:31
verses.text: But the good is not said to be good, on account of its being possessed of virtue; as also righteousness is not said to be good on account of its possessing virtue—for it is itself virtue—but on account of its being in itself and by itself good.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:32
verses.text: In another way the useful is called good, not on account of its pleasing, but of its doing good.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:33
verses.text: All which, therefore, is righteousness, being a good thing, both as virtue and as desirable for its own sake, and not as giving pleasure; for it does not judge in order to win favour, but dispenses to each according to his merits.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:34
verses.text: And the beneficial follows the useful.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:35
verses.text: Righteousness, therefore, has characteristics corresponding to all the aspects in which goodness is examined, both possessing equal properties equally.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:36
verses.text: And things which are characterized by equal properties are equal and similar to each other.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:37
verses.text: Righteousness is therefore a good thing.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:38
verses.text: "How then," say they, "if the Lord loves man, and is good, is He angry and punishes?" We must therefore treat of this point with all possible brevity; for this mode of treatment is advantageous to the right training of the children, occupying the place of a necessary help.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:39
verses.text: For many of the passions are cured by punishment, and by the inculcation of the sterner precepts, as also by instruction in certain principles.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:40
verses.text: For reproof is, as it were, the surgery of the passions of the soul; and the passions are, as it were, an abscess of the truth, which must be cut open by an incision of the lancet of reproof.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:41
verses.text: Reproach is like the application of medicines, dissolving the callosities of the passions, and purging the impurities of the lewdness of the life; and in addition, reducing the excrescences of pride, restoring the patient to the healthy and true state of humanity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:42
verses.text: Admonition is, as it were, the regimen of the diseased soul, prescribing what it must take, and forbidding what it must not.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:43
verses.text: And all these tend to salvation and eternal health.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:44
verses.text: Furthermore, the general of an army, by inflicting fines and corporeal punishments with chains and the extremest disgrace on offenders,  and sometimes even by punishing individuals with death, aims at good, doing so for the admonition of the officers under him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:45
verses.text: Thus also He who is our great General, the Word, the Commander-in-chief of the universe, by admonishing those who throw off the restraints of His law, that He may effect their release from the slavery, error, and captivity of the adversary, brings them peacefully to the sacred concord of citizenship.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:46
verses.text: As, therefore in addition to persuasive discourse, there is the hortatory and the consolatory form; so also, in addition to the laudatory, there is the inculpatory and reproachful.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:47
verses.text: And this latter constitutes the art of censure.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:48
verses.text: Now censure is a mark of good-will, not of ill-will.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:49
verses.text: For both he who is a friend and he who is not, reproach; but the enemy does so in scorn, the friend in kindness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:50
verses.text: It is not, then, from hatred that the Lord chides men; for He Himself suffered for us, whom He might have destroyed for our faults.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:51
verses.text: For the Instructor also, in virtue of His being good, with consummate art glides into censure by rebuke; rousing the sluggishness of the mind by His sharp words as by a scourge.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:52
verses.text: Again in turn He endeavours to exhort the same persons.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:53
verses.text: For those who are not induced by praise are spurred on by censure; and those whom censure calls not forth to salvation being as dead, are by denunciation roused to the truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:54
verses.text: "For the stripes and correction of wisdom are in all time".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:55
verses.text: "For teaching a fool is gluing a potsherd; and sharpening to sense a hopeless blockhead is bringing earth to sensation".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:56
verses.text: Wherefore He adds plainly, "rousing the sleeper from deep sleep," which of all things else is likest death.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:57
verses.text: Further, the Lord shows very clearly of Himself, when, describing figuratively His manifold and in many ways serviceable culture,—He says, "I am the true vine, and my Father is the husbandman".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:58
verses.text: Then He adds, "Every branch in me that beareth not fruit He taketh away; and every branch that beareth fruit He pruneth, that it may bring forth more fruit".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:59
verses.text: For the vine that is not pruned grows to wood.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:60
verses.text: So also man.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:61
verses.text: The Word—the knife—clears away the wanton shoots; compelling the impulses of the soul to fructify, not to indulge in lust.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:62
verses.text: Now, reproof addressed to sinners has their salvation for its aim, the word being harmoniously adjusted to each one's conduct; now with tightened, now with relaxed cords.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:63
verses.text: Accordingly it was very plainly said by Moses, "Be of good courage: God has drawn near to try you, that His fear may be among you, that ye sin not".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:64
verses.text: And Plato, who had learned from this source, says beautifully: "For all who suffer punishment are in reality treated well, for they are benefited; since the spirit of those who are justly punished is improved".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:65
verses.text: And if those who are corrected receive good at the hands of justice, and, according to Plato, what is just is acknowledged to be good, fear itself does good, and has been found to be for men's good.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:66
verses.text: "For the soul that feareth the Lord shall live, for their hope is in Him who saveth them".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:67
verses.text: And this same Word who inflicts punishment is judge; regarding whom Esaias also says, "The Lord has assigned Him to our sins," plainly as a corrector and reformer of sins.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:68
verses.text: Wherefore He alone is able to forgive our iniquities, who has been appointed by the Father, Instructor of us all; He alone it is who is able to distinguish between disobedience and obedience.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:69
verses.text: And while He threatens, He manifestly is unwilling to inflict evil to execute His threatenings; but by inspiring men with fear, He cuts off the approach to sin, and shows His love to man, still delaying, and declaring what they shall suffer if they continue sinners, and is not as a serpent, which the moment it fastens on its prey devours it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:70
verses.text: God, then, is good.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:71
verses.text: And the Lord speaks many a time and oft before He proceeds to act.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:72
verses.text: "For my arrows," He says, "will make an end of them; they shall be consumed with hunger, and be eaten by birds; and there shall be incurable tetanic incurvature.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:73
verses.text: I will send the teeth of wild beasts upon them, with the rage of serpents creeping on the earth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:74
verses.text: Without, the sword shall make them childless; and out of their chambers shall be fear".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:75
verses.text: For the Divine Being is not angry in the way that some think; but often restrains, and always exhorts humanity, and shows what ought to be done.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:76
verses.text: And this is a good device, to terrify lest we sin.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:77
verses.text: "For the fear of the Lord drives away sins, and he that is without fear cannot be justified," says the Scripture.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:78
verses.text: And God does not inflict punishment from wrath, but for the ends of justice; since it is not expedient that justice should be neglected on our account.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:79
verses.text: Each one of us, who sins, with his own free-will chooses punishment, and the blame lies with him who chooses.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:80
verses.text: God is without blame.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:81
verses.text: "But if our unrighteousness commend the righteousness of God, what shall we say? Is God unrighteous, who taketh vengeance? God forbid".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:82
verses.text: He says, therefore, threatening, "I will sharpen my sword, and my hand shall lay hold on judgment; and I will render justice to mine enemies, and requite those who hate me.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:83
verses.text: I will make mine arrows drunk with blood, and my sword shall devour  flesh from the blood of the wounded".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:84
verses.text: It is clear, then, that those who are not at enmity with the truth, and do not hate the Word, will not hate their own salvation, but will escape the punishment of enmity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:85
verses.text: "The crown of wisdom," then, as the book of Wisdom says, "is the fear of the Lord".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:86
verses.text: Very clearly, therefore, by the prophet Amos has the Lord unfolded His method of dealing, saying, "I have overthrown you, as God overthrew Sodom and Gomorrah; and ye shall be as a brand plucked from the fire: and yet ye have not returned unto me, saith the Lord".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:87
verses.text: See how God, through His love of goodness, seeks repentance; and by means of the plan He pursues of threatening silently, shows His own love for man.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:88
verses.text: "I will avert," He says, "My face from them, and show what shall happen to them".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:89
verses.text: For where the face of the Lord looks, there is peace and rejoicing; but where it is averted, there is the introduction of evil.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:90
verses.text: The Lord, accordingly, does not wish to look on evil things; for He is good.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:91
verses.text: But on His looking away, evil arises spontaneously through human unbelief.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:92
verses.text: "Behold, therefore," says Paul, "the goodness and severity of God: on them that fell, severity; but upon thee, goodness, if thou continue in His goodness," that is, in faith in Christ.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:93
verses.text: Now hatred of evil attends the good man, in virtue of His being in nature good.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:94
verses.text: Wherefore I will grant that He punishes the disobedient (for punishment is for the good and advantage of him who is punished, for it is the correction of a refractory subject); but I will not grant that He wishes to take vengeance.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:95
verses.text: Revenge is retribution for evil, imposed for the advantage of him who takes the revenge.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:96
verses.text: He will not desire us to take revenge, who teaches us "to pray for those that despitefully use us".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:97
verses.text: But that God is good, all willingly admit; and that the same God is just, I require not many more words to prove, after adducing the evangelical utterance of the Lord; He speaks of Him as one, "That they all may be one; as Thou, Father, art in Me, and I in Thee, that they also may be one in Us: that the world also may believe that Thou hast sent Me.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:98
verses.text: And the glory which Thou hast given Me I have given them; that they may be one, as We are one: I in them, and Thou in Me, that they may be made perfect in one".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:99
verses.text: God is one, and beyond the one and above the Monad itself.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:100
verses.text: Wherefore also the particle "Thou," having a demonstrative emphasis, points out God, who alone truly is, "who was, and is, and is to come," in which three divisions of time the one name (ὀ ὤν); "who is," has its place.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:101
verses.text: And that He who alone is God is also alone and truly righteous, our Lord in the Gospel itself shall testify, saying "Father, I will that they also whom Thou hast given Me be with Me where I am; that they may behold My glory, which Thou hast given Me: For Thou lovedst Me before the foundation of the world.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:102
verses.text: O righteous Father, the world hath not known Thee: but I have known Thee, and these have known that Thou hast sent Me.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:103
verses.text: And I have declared to them Thy name, and will declare it".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:104
verses.text: This is He "that visits the iniquities of the fathers upon the children, to them that hate Him, and shows mercy to those that love Him".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:105
verses.text: For He who placed some "on the right hand, and others on the left," conceived as Father, being good, is called that which alone He is—"good;" but as He is the Son in the Father, being his Word, from their mutual relation, the name of power being measured by equality of love, He is called righteous.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:106
verses.text: "He will judge," He says, "a man according to his works,"—a good balance, even God having made known to us the face of righteousness in the person of Jesus, by whom also, as by even scales, we know God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:107
verses.text: Of this also the book of Wisdom plainly says, "For mercy and wrath are with Him, for He alone is Lord of both," Lord of propitiations, and pouring forth wrath according to the abundance of His mercy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:108
verses.text: "So also is His reproof".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:109
verses.text: For the aim of mercy and of reproof is the salvation of those who are reproved.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:110
verses.text: Now, that the God and Father of our Lord Jesus is good, the Word Himself will again avouch: "For He is kind to the unthankful and the evil;" and further, when He says, "Be merciful, as your Father is merciful".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:111
verses.text: Still further also He plainly says, "None is good, but My Father, who is in heaven".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:112
verses.text: In addition to these, again He says, "My Father makes His sun to shine on all".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:113
verses.text: Here it is to be noted that He proclaims His Father to be good, and to be the Creator.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:114
verses.text: And that the Creator is just, is not disputed.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:115
verses.text: And again he says, "My Father sends rain on the just, and on the unjust".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:116
verses.text: In respect of His sending rain, He is the Creator of the waters, and of the clouds.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:117
verses.text: And in respect of His doing so on all, He holds an even balance justly and rightly.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:118
verses.text: And as being good, He does so on just and unjust alike.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:119
verses.text: Very clearly, then, we conclude Him to be one and the same God, thus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:120
verses.text: For the Holy Spirit has sung, "I will look to the heavens, the works  of Thy hands;" and, "He who created the heavens dwells in the heavens;" and, "Heaven is Thy throne".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:121
verses.text: And the Lord says in His prayer, "Our Father, who art in heaven".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:122
verses.text: And the heavens belong to Him, who created the world.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:123
verses.text: It is indisputable, then, that the Lord is the Son of the Creator.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:124
verses.text: And if, the Creator above all is confessed to be just, and the Lord to be the Son of the Creator; then the Lord is the Son of Him who is just.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:125
verses.text: Wherefore also Paul says, "But now the righteousness of God without the law is manifested;" and again, that you may better conceive of God, "even the righteousness of God by the faith of Jesus Christ upon all that believe; for there is no difference".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:126
verses.text: And, witnessing further to the truth, he adds after a little, "through the forbearance of God, in order to show that He is just, and that Jesus is the justifier of him who is of faith".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:127
verses.text: And that he knows that what is just is good, appears by his saying, "So that the law is holy, and the commandment holy, and just, and good," using both names to denote the same power.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:128
verses.text: But "no one is good," except His Father.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:129
verses.text: It is this same Father of His, then, who being one is manifested by many powers.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:130
verses.text: And this was the import of the utterance, "No man knew the Father," who was Himself everything before the coming of the Son.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:131
verses.text: So that it is veritably clear that the God of all is only one good, just Creator, and the Son in the Father, to whom be glory for ever and ever, Amen.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:132
verses.text: But it is not inconsistent with the saving Word, to administer rebuke dictated by solicitude.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:133
verses.text: For this is the medicine of the divine love to man, by which the blush of modesty breaks forth, and shame at sin supervenes.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:134
verses.text: For if one must censure, it is necessary also to rebuke; when it is the time to wound the apathetic soul not mortally, but salutarily, securing exemption from everlasting death by a little pain.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:135
verses.text: Great is the wisdom displayed in His instruction, and manifold the modes of His dealing in order to salvation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:136
verses.text: For the Instructor testifies to the good, and summons forth to better things those that are called; dissuades those that are hastening to do wrong from the attempt, and exhorts them to turn to a better life.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:137
verses.text: For the one is not without testimony, when the other has been testified to; and the grace which proceeds from the testimony is very great.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 7:138
verses.text: Besides, the feeling of anger (if it is proper to call His admonition anger) is full of love to man, God condescending to emotion on man's account; for whose sake also the Word of God became man.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:1
verses.text: Chapter 9—That It is the Prerogative of the Same Power to Be Beneficent and to Punish Justly.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:2
verses.text: Also the Manner of the Instruction of the Logos.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:3
verses.text: With all His power, therefore, the Instructor of humanity, the Divine Word, using all the resources of wisdom, devotes Himself to the saving of the children, admonishing, upbraiding, blaming, chiding, reproving, threatening, healing, promising, favouring; and as it were, by many reins, curbing the irrational impulses of humanity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:4
verses.text: To speak briefly, therefore, the Lord acts towards us as we do towards our children.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:5
verses.text: "Hast thou children? correct them," is the exhortation of the book of Wisdom, "and bend them from their youth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:6
verses.text: Hast thou daughters? attend to their body, and let not thy face brighten towards them,"—although we love our children exceedingly, both sons and daughters, above aught else whatever.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:7
verses.text: For those who speak with a man merely to please him, have little love for him, seeing they do not pain him; while those that speak for his good, though they inflict pain for the time, do him good for ever after.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:8
verses.text: It is not immediate pleasure, but future enjoyment, that the Lord has in view.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:9
verses.text: Let us now proceed to consider the mode of His loving discipline, with the aid of the prophetic testimony.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:10
verses.text: Admonition, then, is the censure of loving care, and produces understanding.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:11
verses.text: Such is the Instructor in His admonitions, as when He says in the Gospel, "How often would I have gathered thy children, as a bird gathers her young ones under her wings, and ye would not!" And again, the Scripture admonishes, saying, "And they committed adultery with stock and stone, and burnt incense to Baal".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:12
verses.text: For it is a very great proof of His love, that, though knowing well the shamelessness of the people that had kicked and bounded away, He notwithstanding exhorts them to repentance, and says by Ezekiel, "Son of man, thou dwellest in the midst of scorpions; nevertheless, speak to them, if peradventure they will hear".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:13
verses.text: Further, to Moses He says, "Go and tell Pharaoh to send My people forth; but I know that he will not send them forth".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:14
verses.text: For He shows both things: both His divinity in His foreknowledge of what would take place, and His love in affording an opportunity for repentance to the self-determination of the soul.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:15
verses.text: He admonishes also by Esaias, in His care for the people, when He says, "This people honour Me with their lips, but their heart is far from Me".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:16
verses.text: What follows is reproving censure: "In vain do they worship  Me, teaching for doctrines the commandments of men".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:17
verses.text: Here His loving care, having shown their sin, shows salvation side by side.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:18
verses.text: Upbraiding is censure on account of what is base, conciliating to what is noble.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:19
verses.text: This is shown by Jeremiah: "They were female-mad horses; each one neighed after his neighbour's wife.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:20
verses.text: Shall I not visit for these things? saith the Lord: shall not my soul be avenged on such a nation as this?" He everywhere interweaves fear, because "the fear of the Lord is the beginning of sense".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:21
verses.text: And again, by Hosea, He says, "Shall I not visit them? for they themselves were mingled with harlots, and sacrificed with the initiated; and the people that understood embraced a harlot".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:22
verses.text: He shows their offence to be clearer, by declaring that they understood, and thus sinned wilfully.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:23
verses.text: Understanding is the eye of the soul; wherefore also Israel means, "he that sees God"—that is, he that understands God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:24
verses.text: Complaint is censure of those who are regarded as despising or neglecting.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:25
verses.text: He employs this form when He says by Esaias: "Hear, O heaven; and give ear, O earth: for the Lord hath spoken, I have begotten and brought up children, but they have disregarded Me.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:26
verses.text: The ox knoweth his owner, and the ass his master's crib: but Israel hath not known Me".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:27
verses.text: For how shall we not regard it fearful, if he that knows God, shall not recognise the Lord; but while the ox and the ass, stupid and foolish animals, will know him who feeds them, Israel is found to be more irrational than these? And having, by Jeremiah, complained against the people on many grounds, He adds: "And they have forsaken Me, saith the Lord".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:28
verses.text: Invective is a reproachful upbraiding, or chiding censure.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:29
verses.text: This mode of treatment the Instructor employs in Isaiah, when He says, "Woe to you, children revolters.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:30
verses.text: Thus saith the Lord, Ye have taken counsel, but not by Me; and made compacts, but not by My Spirit".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:31
verses.text: He uses the very bitter mordant of fear in each case repressing the people, and at the same time turning them to salvation; as also wool that is undergoing the process of dyeing is wont to be previously treated with mordants, in order to prepare it for taking on a fast colour.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:32
verses.text: Reproof is the bringing forward of sin, laying it before one.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:33
verses.text: This form of instruction He employs as in the highest degree necessary, by reason of the feebleness of the faith of many.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:34
verses.text: For He says by Esaias, "Ye have forsaken the Lord, and have provoked the Holy One of Israel to anger".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:35
verses.text: And He says also by Jeremiah: "Heaven was astonished at this, and the earth shuddered exceedingly.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:36
verses.text: For My people have committed two evils; they have forsaken Me, the fountain of living waters, and have hewn out to themselves broken cisterns, which will not be able to hold water".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:37
verses.text: And again, by the same: "Jerusalem hath sinned a sin; therefore it became commotion.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:38
verses.text: All that glorified her dishonoured her, when they saw her baseness".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:39
verses.text: And He uses the bitter and biting language of reproof in His consolations by Solomon, tacitly alluding to the love for children that characterizes His instruction: "My son, despise not thou the chastening of the Lord; nor faint when thou art rebuked of Him: for whom the Lord loveth He chasteneth, and scourgeth every son whom He receiveth;" "For a man who is a sinner escapes reproof".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:40
verses.text: Consequently, therefore, the Scripture says, "Let the righteous reprove and correct me; but let not the oil of the sinner anoint my head".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:41
verses.text: Bringing one to his senses (φρένωσις) is censure, which makes a man think.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:42
verses.text: Neither from this form of instruction does he abstain, but says by Jeremiah, "How long shall I cry, and you not hear? So your ears are uncircumcised".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:43
verses.text: O blessed forbearance! And again, by the same: "All the heathen are uncircumcised, but this people is uncircumcised in heart:" "for the people are disobedient; children," says He, "in whom is not faith".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:44
verses.text: Visitation is severe rebuke.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:45
verses.text: He uses this species in the Gospel: "O Jerusalem, Jerusalem, that killest the prophets, and stonest them that are sent unto thee!" The reduplication of the name gives strength to the rebuke.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:46
verses.text: For he that knows God, how does he persecute God's servants? Wherefore He says, "Your house is left desolate; for I say unto you, Henceforth ye shall not see Me, till ye shall say, Blessed is He that cometh in the name of the Lord".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:47
verses.text: For if you do not receive His love, ye shall know His power.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:48
verses.text: Denunciation is vehement speech.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:49
verses.text: And He employs denunciation as medicine, by Isaiah, saying, "Ah, sinful nation, lawless sons, people full of sins, wicked seed!" And in the Gospel by John He says, "Serpents, brood of vipers".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:50
verses.text: Accusation is censure of wrong-doers.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:51
verses.text: This mode of instruction He employs by David, when He says: "The people whom I knew not served me, and at the hearing of the ear obeyed me.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:52
verses.text: Sons of strangers lied to me, and halted from their ways".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:53
verses.text: And by Jeremiah: "And I gave her a writing of divorcement, and covenant-breaking Judah feared not".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:54
verses.text: And again: "And the house of Israel disregarded Me; and the house of Judah lied to the Lord".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:55
verses.text: Bewailing one's fate is latent censure, and by artful aid ministers salvation as under a veil.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:56
verses.text: He made use of this by Jeremiah: "How did the city sit solitary that was full of people! She that ruled over territories became as a widow; she came under tribute; weeping, she wept in the night".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:57
verses.text: Objurgation is objurgatory censure.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:58
verses.text: Of this help the Divine Instructor made use by Jeremiah, saying, "Thou hadst a whore's forehead; thou wast shameless towards all; and didst not call me to the house, who am thy father, and lord of thy virginity".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:59
verses.text: "And a fair and graceful harlot skilled in enchanted potions".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:60
verses.text: With consummate art, after applying to the virgin the opprobrious name of whoredom, He thereupon calls her back to an honourable life by filling her with shame.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:61
verses.text: Indignation is a rightful upbraiding; or upbraiding on account of ways exalted above what is right.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:62
verses.text: In this way He instructed by Moses, when He said, "Faulty children, a generation crooked and perverse, do ye thus requite the Lord? This people is foolish, and not wise.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:63
verses.text: Is not this thy father who acquired thee?" He says also by Isaiah, "Thy princes are disobedient, companions of thieves, loving gifts, following after rewards, not judging the orphans".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:64
verses.text: In fine, the system He pursues to inspire fear is the source of salvation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:65
verses.text: And it is the prerogative of goodness to save: "The mercy of the Lord is on all flesh, while He reproves, corrects, and teaches as a shepherd His flock.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:66
verses.text: He pities those who receive His instruction, and those who eagerly seek union with Him".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:67
verses.text: And with such guidance He guarded the six hundred thousand footmen that were brought together in the hardness of heart in which they were found; scourging, pitying, striking, healing, in compassion and discipline: "For according to the greatness of His mercy, so is His rebuke".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:68
