verses.text: For it is indeed noble not to sin; but it is good also for the sinner to repent; just as it is best to be always in good health, but well to recover from disease.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:69
verses.text: So He commands by Solomon: "Strike thou thy son with the rod, that thou mayest deliver his soul from death".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:70
verses.text: And again: "Abstain not from chastising thy son, but correct him with the rod; for he will not die".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:71
verses.text: For reproof and rebuke, as also the original term implies, are the stripes of the soul, chastizing sins, preventing death, and leading to self-control those carried away to licentiousness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:72
verses.text: Thus also Plato, knowing reproof to be the greatest power for reformation, and the most sovereign purification, in accordance with what has been said, observes, "that he who is in the highest degree impure is uninstructed and base, by reason of his being unreproved in those respects in which he who is destined to be truly happy ought to be purest and best".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:73
verses.text: For if rulers are not a terror to a good work, how shall God, who is by nature good, be a terror to him who sins not? "If thou doest evil, be afraid," says the apostle.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:74
verses.text: Wherefore the apostle himself also in every case uses stringent language to the Churches, after the Lord's example; and conscious of his own boldness, and of the weakness of his hearers, he says to the Galatians: "Am I your enemy, because I tell you the truth?" Thus also people in health do not require a physician, do not require him as long as they are strong; but those who are ill need his skill.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:75
verses.text: Thus also we who in our lives are ill of shameful lusts and reprehensible excesses, and other inflammatory effects of the passions, need the Saviour.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:76
verses.text: And He administers not only mild, but also stringent medicines.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:77
verses.text: The bitter roots of fear then arrest the eating sores of our sins.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:78
verses.text: Wherefore also fear is salutary, if bitter.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:79
verses.text: Sick, we truly stand in need of the Saviour; having wandered, of one to guide us; blind, of one to lead us to the light; thirsty, "of the fountain of life, of which whosoever partakes, shall no longer thirst;" dead, we need life; sheep, we need a shepherd; we who are children need a tutor, while universal humanity stands in need of Jesus; so that we may not continue intractable and sinners to the end, and thus fall into condemnation, but may be separated from the chaff, and stored up in the paternal garner.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:80
verses.text: "For the fan is in the Lord's hand, by which the chaff due to the fire is separated from the wheat".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:81
verses.text: You may learn, if you will, the crowning wisdom of the all-holy Shepherd and Instructor, of the omnipotent and paternal Word, when He figuratively represents Himself as the Shepherd of the sheep.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:82
verses.text: And He is the Tutor of the  children.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:83
verses.text: He says therefore by Ezekiel, directing His discourse to the elders, and setting before them a salutary description of His wise solicitude: "And that which is lame I will bind up, and that which is sick I will heal, and that which has wandered I will turn back; and I will feed them on my holy mountain".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:84
verses.text: Such are the promises of the good Shepherd.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:85
verses.text: Feed us, the children, as sheep.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:86
verses.text: Yea, Master, fill us with righteousness, Thine own pasture; yea, O Instructor, feed us on Thy holy mountain the Church, which towers aloft, which is above the clouds, which touches heaven.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:87
verses.text: "And I will be," He says, "their Shepherd," and will be near them, as the garment to their skin.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:88
verses.text: He wishes to save my flesh by enveloping it in the robe of immortality, and He hath anointed my body.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:89
verses.text: "They shall call Me," He says, "and I will say, Here am I".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:90
verses.text: Thou didst hear sooner than I expected, Master.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:91
verses.text: "And if they pass over, they shall not slip," saith the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:92
verses.text: For we who are passing over to immortality shall not fall into corruption, for He shall sustain us.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:93
verses.text: For so He has said, and so He has willed.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:94
verses.text: Such is our Instructor, righteously good.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:95
verses.text: "I came not," He says, "to be ministered unto, but to minister".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:96
verses.text: Wherefore He is introduced in the Gospel "wearied," because toiling for us, and promising "to give His life a ransom for many".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:97
verses.text: For him alone who does so He owns to be the good shepherd.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:98
verses.text: Generous, therefore, is He who gives for us the greatest of all gifts, His own life; and beneficent exceedingly, and loving to men, in that, when He might have been Lord, He wished to be a brother man; and so good was He that He died for us.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:99
verses.text: Further, His righteousness cried, "If ye come straight to me, I also will come straight to you but if ye walk crooked, I also will walk crooked, saith the Lord of hosts;" meaning by the crooked ways the chastisements of sinners.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:100
verses.text: For the straight and natural way which is indicated by the Iota of the name of Jesus is His goodness, which is firm and sure towards those who have believed at hearing: "When I called, ye obeyed not, saith the Lord; but set at nought my counsels, and heeded not my reproofs".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:101
verses.text: Thus the Lord's reproof is most beneficial.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:102
verses.text: David also says of them, "A perverse and provoking race; a race which set not their heart aright, and whose spirit was not faithful with God: they kept not the covenant of God, and would not walk in His law".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:103
verses.text: Such are the causes of provocation for which the Judge comes to inflict punishment on those that would not choose a life of goodness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:104
verses.text: Wherefore also afterwards He assailed them more roughly; in order, if possible, to drag them back from their impetuous rush towards death.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:105
verses.text: He therefore tells by David the most manifest cause of the threatening: "They believed not in His wonderful works.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:106
verses.text: When He slew them, they sought after Him, and turned and inquired early after God; and remembered that God was their Helper, and God the Most High their Redeemer".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:107
verses.text: Thus He knew that they turned for fear, while they despised His love: for, for the most part, that goodness which is always mild is despised; but He who admonishes by the loving fear of righteousness is reverenced.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:108
verses.text: There is a twofold species of fear, the one of which is accompanied with reverence, such as citizens show towards good rulers, and we towards God, as also right-minded children towards their fathers.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:109
verses.text: "For an unbroken horse turns out unmanageable, and a son who is let take his own way turns out reckless".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:110
verses.text: The other species of fear is accompanied with hatred, which slaves feel towards hard masters, and the Hebrews felt, who made God a master, not a father.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:111
verses.text: And as far as piety is concerned, that which is voluntary and spontaneous differs much, nay entirely, from what is forced.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:112
verses.text: "For He," it is said, "is merciful; He will heal their sins, and not destroy them, and fully turn away His anger, and not kindle all His wrath".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:113
verses.text: See how the justice of the Instructor, which deals in rebukes, is shown; and the goodness of God, which deals in compassions.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:114
verses.text: Wherefore David—that is, the Spirit by him—embracing them both, sings of God Himself, "Justice and judgment are the preparation of His throne: mercy and truth shall go before Thy face".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:115
verses.text: He declares that it belongs to the same power both to judge and to do good.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:116
verses.text: For there is power over both together, and judgment separates that which is just from its opposite.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:117
verses.text: And He who is truly God is just and good; who is Himself all, and all is He; for He is God, the only God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:118
verses.text: For as the mirror is not evil to an ugly man because it shows him what like he is; and as the physician is not evil to the sick man because he tells him of his fever,—for the physician is not the cause of the fever, but only points out the fever;—so neither is He, that reproves, ill-disposed towards him who is diseased in soul.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:119
verses.text: For He does not put the transgressions on him, but only shows the sins which are there; in order to turn him away from similar practices.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:120
verses.text: So  God is good on His own account, and just also on ours, and He is just because He is good.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:121
verses.text: And His justice is shown to us by His own Word from there from above, whence the Father was.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:122
verses.text: For before He became Creator He was God; He was good.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:123
verses.text: And therefore He wished to be Creator and Father.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:124
verses.text: And the nature of all that love was the source of righteousness—the cause, too, of His lighting up His sun, and sending down His own Son.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:125
verses.text: And He first announced the good righteousness that is from heaven, when He said, "No man knoweth the Son, but the Father; nor the Father, but the Son".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:126
verses.text: This mutual and reciprocal knowledge is the symbol of primeval justice.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:127
verses.text: Then justice came down to men both in the letter and in the body, in the Word and in the law, constraining humanity to saving repentance; for it was good.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 8:128
verses.text: But do you not obey God? Then blame yourself, who drag to yourself the judge.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 9

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 9:1
verses.text: Chapter 10—That the Same God, by the Same Word, Restrains from Sin by Threatening, and Saves Humanity by Exhorting.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 9:2
verses.text: If, then, we have shown that the plan of dealing stringently with humanity is good and salutary, and necessarily adopted by the Word, and conducive to repentance and the prevention of sins; we shall have now to look in order at the mildness of the Word.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 9:3
verses.text: For He has been demonstrated to be just.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 9:4
verses.text: He sets before us His own inclinations which invite to salvation; by which, in accordance with the Father's will, He wishes to make known to us the good and the useful.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 9:5
verses.text: Consider these.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 9:6
verses.text: The good (τὸ καλόν) belongs to the panegyrical form of speech, the useful to the persuasive.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 9:7
verses.text: For the hortatory and the dehortatory are a form of the persuasive, and the laudatory and inculpatory of the panegyrical.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 9:8
verses.text: For the persuasive style of sentence in one form becomes hortatory, and in another dehortatory.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 9:9
verses.text: So also the panegyrical in one form becomes inculpatory, and in another laudatory.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 9:10
verses.text: And in these exercises the Instructor, the Just One, who has proposed our advantage as His aim, is chiefly occupied.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 9:11
verses.text: But the inculpatory and dehortatory forms of speech have been already shown us; and we must now handle the persuasive and the laudatory, and, as on a beam, balance the equal scales of justice.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 9:12
verses.text: The exhortation to what is useful, the Instructor employs by Solomon, to the following effect: "I exhort you, O men; and I utter my voice to the sons of men.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 9:13
verses.text: Hear me; for I will speak of excellent things;" and so on.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 9:14
verses.text: And He counsels what is salutary: for counsel has for its end, choosing or refusing a certain course; as He does by David, when He says, "Blessed is the man who walketh not in the counsels of the ungodly, and standeth not in the way of sinners, and sitteth not in the chair of pestilences; but his will is in the law of the Lord".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 9:15
verses.text: And there are three departments of counsel: That which takes examples from past times; as what the Hebrews suffered when they worshipped the golden calf, and what they suffered when they committed fornication, and the like.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 9:16
verses.text: The second, whose meaning is understood from the present times, as being apprehended by perception; as it was said to those who asked the Lord, "If He was the Christ, or shall we wait for another? Go and tell John, the blind receive their sight, the deaf hear, the lepers are cleansed, the dead are raised up; and blessed is he who shall not be offended in Me".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 9:17
verses.text: Such was that which David said when he prophesied, "As we have heard, so have we seen".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 9:18
verses.text: And the third department of counsel consists of what is future, by which we are bidden guard against what is to happen; as also that was said, "They that fall into sins shall be cast into outer darkness, where there shall be wailing and gnashing of teeth," and the like.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 9:19
verses.text: So that from these things it is clear that the Lord, going the round of all the methods of curative treatment, calls humanity to salvation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 9:20
verses.text: By encouragement He assuages sins, reducing lust, and at the same time inspiring hope for salvation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 9:21
verses.text: For He says by Ezekiel, "If ye return with your whole heart, and say, Father, I will hear you, as a holy people".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 9:22
verses.text: And again He says, "Come all to Me, who labour, and are heavy laden, and I will give you rest;" and that which is added the Lord speaks in His own person.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 9:23
verses.text: And very clearly He calls to goodness by Solomon, when He says, "Blessed is the man who hath found wisdom, and the mortal who hath found understanding".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 9:24
verses.text: "For the good is found by him who seeks it, and is wont to be seen by him who has found it".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 9:25
verses.text: By Jeremiah, too, He sets forth prudence, when he says, "Blessed are we, Israel; for what is pleasing to God is known by us;—and it is known by the Word, by whom we are blessed and wise.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 9:26
verses.text: For wisdom and knowledge are mentioned by the same prophet, when he says, "Hear, O Israel, the commandments of life, and give ear to know understanding".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 9:27
verses.text: By Moses, too, by reason of the love He has to man, He promises a gift to those who hasten to salvation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 9:28
verses.text: For He says, "And I will bring you into the good land,  which the Lord sware to your fathers".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 9:29
verses.text: And further, "And I will bring you into the holy mountain, and make you glad," He says by Isaiah.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 9:30
verses.text: And still another form of instruction is benediction.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 9:31
verses.text: "And blessed is he," He saith by David, "who has not sinned; and he shall be as the tree planted near the channels of the waters, which will yield its fruit in its season, and his leaf shall not wither" (by this He made an allusion to the resurrection); "and whatsoever he shall do shall prosper with him".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 9:32
verses.text: Such He wishes us to be, that we may be blessed.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 9:33
verses.text: Again, showing the opposite scale of the balance of justice, He says, "But not so the ungodly—not so; but as the dust which the wind sweeps away from the face of the earth".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 9:34
verses.text: By showing the punishment of sinners, and their easy dispersion, and carrying off by the wind, the Instructor dissuades from crime by means of punishment; and by holding up the merited penalty, shows the benignity of His beneficence in the most skilful way, in order that we may possess and enjoy its blessings.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 9:35
verses.text: He invites us to knowledge also, when He says by Jeremiah, "Hadst thou walked in the way of God, thou wouldst have dwelt for ever in peace;" for, exhibiting there the reward of knowledge, He calls the wise to the love of it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 9:36
verses.text: And, granting pardon to him who has erred, He says, "Turn, turn, as a grape-gatherer to his basket".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 9:37
verses.text: Do you see the goodness of justice, in that it counsels to repentance? And still further, by Jeremiah, He enlightens in the truth those who have erred.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 9:38
verses.text: "Thus saith the Lord, Stand in the ways, and look, and ask for the eternal paths of the Lord, what is the good path, and walk in it, and ye shall find purification for your souls".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 9:39
verses.text: And in order to promote our salvation, He leads us to repentance.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 9:40
verses.text: Wherefore He says, "If thou repent, the Lord will purify thy heart, and the heart of thy seed".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 9:41
verses.text: We might have adduced, as supporters on this question, the philosophers who say that only the perfect man is worthy of praise, and the bad man of blame.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 9:42
verses.text: But since some slander beatitude, as neither itself taking any trouble, nor giving any to any one else, thus not understanding its love to man; on their account, and on account of those who do not associate justice with goodness, the following remarks are added.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 9:43
verses.text: For it were a legitimate inference to say, that rebuke and censure are suitable to men, since they say that all men are bad; but God alone is wise, from whom cometh wisdom, and alone perfect, and therefore alone worthy of praise.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 9:44
verses.text: But I do not employ such language.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 9:45
verses.text: I say, then, that praise or blame, or whatever resembles praise or blame, are medicines most essential of all to men.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 9:46
verses.text: Some are ill to cure, and, like iron, are wrought into shape with fire, and hammer, and anvil, that is, with threatening, and reproof, and chastisement; while others, cleaving to faith itself, as self-taught, and as acting of their own free-will, grow by praise:—  "For virtue that is praised Grows like a tree".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 9:47
verses.text: And comprehending this, as it seems to me, the Samian Pythagoras gives the injunction:—  "When you have done base things, rebuke yourself; But when you have done good things, be glad".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 9:48
verses.text: Chiding is also called admonishing; and the etymology of admonishing (νουθέτησις) is (νοῦ ἐνθεματισμός) putting of understanding into one; so that rebuking is bringing one to one's senses.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 9:49
verses.text: But there are myriads of injunctions to be found, whose aim is the attainment of what is good, and the avoidance of what is evil.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 9:50
verses.text: "For there is no peace to the wicked, saith the Lord".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 9:51
verses.text: Wherefore by Solomon He commands the children to beware: "My son, let not sinners deceive thee, and go not after their ways; and go not, if they entice thee, saying, Come with us, share with us in innocent blood, and let us hide unjustly the righteous man in the earth; let us put him out of sight, all alive as he is into Hades".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 9:52
verses.text: This is accordingly likewise a prediction concerning the Lord's passion.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 9:53
verses.text: And by Ezekiel, the life supplies commandments: "The soul that sinneth shall die; but he that doeth righteousness shall be righteous.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 9:54
verses.text: He eateth not upon the mountains, and hath not set his eyes on the devices of the house of Israel, and will not defile his neighbour's wife, and will not approach to a woman in her separation, and will not oppress a man, and will restore the debtor's pledge, and will not take plunder: he will give his bread to the hungry, and clothe the naked.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 9:55
verses.text: His money he will not give on usury, and will not take interest; and he will turn away his hand from wrong, and will execute righteous judgment between a man and his neighbour.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 9:56
verses.text: He has walked in my statutes, and kept my judgments to do them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 9:57
verses.text: This is a righteous man.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 9:58
verses.text: He shall surely live, saith the Lord".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 9:59
verses.text: These words contain a description of the conduct of Christians, a notable exhortation to the blessed life, which is the reward of a life of goodness—everlasting life.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 10

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 10:1
verses.text: Chapter 11—That the Word Instructed by the Law and the Prophets.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 10:2
verses.text: The mode of His love and His instruction we have shown as we could.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 10:3
verses.text: Wherefore He Himself, declaring Himself very beautifully, likened Himself to a grain of mustard-seed; and pointed out the spirituality of the word that is sown, and the productiveness of its nature, and the magnificence and conspicuousness of the power of the word; and besides, intimated that the pungency and the purifying virtue of punishment are profitable on account of its sharpness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 10:4
verses.text: By the little grain, as it is figuratively called, He bestows salvation on all humanity abundantly.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 10:5
verses.text: Honey, being very sweet, generates bile, as goodness begets contempt, which is the cause of sinning.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 10:6
verses.text: But mustard lessens bile, that is, anger, and stops inflammation, that is, pride.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 10:7
verses.text: From which Word springs the true health of the soul, and its eternal happy temperament (εὐκρασία).

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 10:8
verses.text: Accordingly, of old He instructed by Moses, and then by the prophets.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 10:9
verses.text: Moses, too, was a prophet.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 10:10
verses.text: For the law is the training of refractory children.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 10:11
verses.text: "Having feasted to the full," accordingly, it is said, "they rose up to play;" senseless repletion with victuals being called χόρτασμα (fodder), not βρῶμα (food).

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 10:12
verses.text: And when, having senselessly filled themselves, they senselessly played; on that account the law was given them, and terror ensued for the prevention of transgressions and for the promotion of right actions, securing attention, and so winning to obedience to the true Instructor, being one and the same Word, and reducing to conformity with the urgent demands of the law.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 10:13
verses.text: For Paul says that it was given to be a "schoolmaster to bring us to Christ".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 10:14
verses.text: So that from this it is clear, that one alone, true, good, just, in the image and likeness of the Father, His Son Jesus, the Word of God, is our Instructor; to whom God hath entrusted us, as an affectionate father commits his children to a worthy tutor, expressly charging us, "This is my beloved Son: hear Him".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 10:15
verses.text: The divine Instructor is trustworthy, adorned as He is with three of the fairest ornament"—knowledge, benevolence, and authority of utterance;—with knowledge, for He is the paternal wisdom: "All Wisdom is from the Lord, and with Him for evermore;"—with authority of utterance, for He is God and Creator: "For all things were made by Him, and without Him was not anything made;"—and with benevolence, for He alone gave Himself a sacrifice for us: "For the good Shepherd giveth His life for the sheep;" and He has so given it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 10:16
verses.text: Now, benevolence is nothing but wishing to do good to one's neighbour for his sake.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 11

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 11:1
verses.text: Chapter 12—The Instructor Characterized by the Severity and Benignity of Paternal Affection.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 11:2
verses.text: Having now accomplished those things, it were a fitting sequel that our instructor Jesus should draw for us the model of the true life, and train humanity in Christ.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 11:3
verses.text: Nor is the cast and character of the life He enjoins very formidable; nor is it made altogether easy by reason of His benignity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 11:4
verses.text: He enjoins His commands, and at the same time gives them such a character that they may be accomplished.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 11:5
verses.text: The view I take is, that He Himself formed man of the dust, and regenerated him by water; and made him grow by his Spirit; and trained him by His word to adoption and salvation, directing him by sacred precepts; in order that, transforming earth-born man into a holy and heavenly being by His advent, He might fulfil to the utmost that divine utterance, "Let Us make man in Our own image and likeness".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 11:6
verses.text: And, in truth, Christ became the perfect realization of what God spake; and the rest of humanity is conceived as being created merely in His image.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 11:7
verses.text: But let us, O children of the good Father—nurslings of the good Instructor—fulfil the Father's will, listen to the Word, and take on the impress of the truly saving life of our Saviour; and meditating on the heavenly mode of life according to which we have been deified, let us anoint ourselves with the perennial immortal bloom of gladness—that ointment of sweet fragrance—having a clear example of immortality in the walk and conversation of the Lord; and following the footsteps of God, to whom alone it belongs to consider, and whose care it is to see to, the way and manner in which the life of men may be made more healthy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 11:8
verses.text: Besides, He makes preparation for a self-sufficing mode of life, for simplicity, and for girding up our loins, and for free and unimpeded readiness of our journey; in order to the attainment of an eternity of beatitude, teaching each one of us to be his own storehouse.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 11:9
verses.text: For He says, "Take no anxious thought for to-morrow," meaning that the man who has devoted himself to Christ ought to be sufficient to himself, and servant to himself, and moreover lead a life which provides for each day by itself.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 11:10
verses.text: For it is not in war, but in peace, that  we are trained.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 11:11
verses.text: War needs great preparation, and luxury craves profusion; but peace and love, simple and quiet sisters, require no arms nor excessive preparation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 11:12
verses.text: The Word is their sustenance.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 11:13
verses.text: Our superintendence in instruction and discipline is the office of the Word, from whom we learn frugality and humility, and all that pertains to love of truth, love of man, and love of excellence.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 11:14
verses.text: And so, in a word, being assimilated to God by a participation in moral excellence, we must not retrograde into carelessness and sloth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 11:15
verses.text: But labour, and faint not.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 11:16
verses.text: Thou shalt be what thou dost not hope, and canst not conjecture.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 11:17
verses.text: And as there is one mode of training for philosophers, another for orators, and another for athletes; so is there a generous disposition, suitable to the choice that is set upon moral loveliness, resulting from the training of Christ.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 11:18
verses.text: And in the case of those who have been trained according to this influence, their gait in walking, their sitting at table, their food, their sleep, their going to bed, their regimen, and the rest of their mode of life, acquire a superior dignity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 11:19
verses.text: For such a training as is pursued by the Word is not overstrained, but is of the right tension.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 11:20
verses.text: Thus, therefore, the Word has been called also the Saviour, seeing He has found out for men those rational medicines which produce vigour of the senses and salvation; and devotes Himself to watching for the favourable moment, reproving evil, exposing the causes of evil affections, and striking at the roots of irrational lusts, pointing out what we ought to abstain from, and supplying all the antidotes of salvation to those who are diseased.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 11:21
verses.text: For the greatest and most regal work of God is the salvation of humanity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 11:22
verses.text: The sick are vexed at a physician, who gives no advice bearing on their restoration to health.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 11:23
verses.text: But how shall we not acknowledge the highest gratitude to the divine Instructor, who is not silent, who omits not those threatenings that point towards destruction, but discloses them, and cuts off the impulses that tend to them; and who indoctrinates in those counsels which result in the true way of living? We must confess, therefore, the deepest obligations to Him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 11:24
verses.text: For what else do we say is incumbent on the rational creature—I mean man—than the contemplation of the Divine? I say, too, that it is requisite to contemplate human nature, and to live as the truth directs, and to admire the Instructor and His injunctions, as suitable and harmonious to each other.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 11:25
verses.text: According to which image also we ought, conforming ourselves to the Instructor, and making the word and our deeds agree, to live a real life.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 12

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 12:1
verses.text: Chapter 13—Virtue Rational, Sin Irrational.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 12:2
verses.text: Everything that is contrary to right reason is sin.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 12:3
verses.text: Accordingly, therefore, the philosophers think fit to define the most generic passions thus: lust, as desire disobedient to reason; fear, as weakness disobedient to reason; pleasure, as an elation of the spirit disobedient to reason.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 12:4
verses.text: If, then, disobedience in reference to reason is the generating cause of sin, how shall we escape the conclusion, that obedience to reason—the Word—which we call faith, will of necessity be the efficacious cause of duty? For virtue itself is a state of the soul rendered harmonious by reason in respect to the whole life.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 12:5
verses.text: Nay, to crown all, philosophy itself is pronounced to be the cultivation of right reason; so that, necessarily, whatever is done through error of reason is transgression, and is rightly called, (ἁμάρτημα) sin.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 12:6
verses.text: Since, then, the first man sinned and disobeyed God, it is said, "And man became like to the beasts:" being rightly regarded as irrational, he is likened to the beasts.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 12:7
verses.text: Whence Wisdom says: "The horse for covering; the libidinous and the adulturer is become like to an irrational beast".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 12:8
verses.text: Wherefore also it is added: "He neighs, whoever may be sitting on him".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 12:9
verses.text: The man, it is meant, no longer speaks; for he who transgresses against reason is no longer rational, but an irrational animal, given up to lusts by which he is ridden (as a horse by his rider).

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 12:10
verses.text: But that which is done right, in obedience to reason, the followers of the Stoics call προσῆκον and καθῆκον, that is, incumbent and fitting.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 12:11
verses.text: What is fitting is incumbent.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 12:12
verses.text: And obedience is founded on commands.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 12:13
verses.text: And these being, as they are, the same as counsel—having truth for their aim, train up to the ultimate goal of aspiration, which is conceived of as the end (τέλος).

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 12:14
verses.text: And the end of piety is eternal rest in God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 12:15
verses.text: And the beginning of eternity is our end.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 12:16
verses.text: The right operation of piety perfects duty by works; whence, according to just reasoning, duties consist in actions, not in sayings.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 12:17
verses.text: And Christian conduct is the operation of the rational soul in accordance with a correct judgment and aspiration after the truth, which attains its destined end through the body, the soul's consort and ally.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 12:18
verses.text: Virtue is a will in conformity to God and Christ in life, rightly adjusted to life everlasting.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 12:19
verses.text: For the life of Christians, in which we are now trained, is a system of reasonable actions—that is, of those things taught by the Word—an unfailing energy which we have called faith.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 12:20
verses.text: The system is the commandments of the Lord, which, being divine statues and spiritual counsels, have been written for ourselves, being adapted for ourselves and our neighbours.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 12:21
verses.text: Moreover, they turn back on us, as the ball rebounds on him that throws it by the repercussion.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 12:22
verses.text: Whence also duties are essential for divine discipline, as being enjoined by God, and furnished for our salvation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 12:23
verses.text: And since, of those things which are necessary, some relate only to life here, and others, which relate to the blessed life yonder, wing us for flight hence; so, in an analogous manner, of duties, some are ordained with reference to life, others for the blessed life.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Instructor Book I 12:24
verses.text: The commandments issued with respect to natural life are published to the multitude; but those that are suited for living well, and from which eternal life springs, we have to consider, as in a sketch, as we read them out of the Scriptures.
